title: tims-tales-johnnie-copes-journey
story: I WAS in Lauder last weekend to tell stories to the Lauder Cub Group.It was at the invitation of old friends whose son attends the Cubs there, and afterwards we spent a lovely evening catching up and being amazed how our respective children had grown so much since wersquod last seen each other.My friends had previously lived in Prestonpans, and as the evening wore on there was talk about the memories from their time there, where I still stay.Soon after my friends arrived in Lauder, they discovered a plaque which commemorated the arrival of Johnnie Cope in . Lauder, it is said, was the first place he stopped after fleeing from the Battle of Prestonpans.ldquoI suppose we kind of followed in his footsteps, said my friend, ldquoalthough in a very dferent way and totally dferent circumstances of course. Folk round here donrsquot really know the story, but coming from the Pans it gave us an immediate connection.The actual house on Lauder High Street that Johnnie Cope arrived at is now gone, replaced over  years ago. But Lauder must look much as it did on that fateful day when Cope arrived, with his horse close to collapse with exhaustion.Johnnie Cope was the general commanding the British Army at Prestonpans on that fateful day, September , . The battle was a major victory for the Jacobites. Cope fled the scene of battle, but only when it was clearly lost. He eventually arrived at Berwick-upon-Tweed to give news of his own defeat. Ever since, popular tradition has mocked Cope for running away and not standing his ground and dying lsquohonourablyrsquo, as Colonel Gardiner of Bankton House did.This ridicule was encapsulated in a traditional popular song, and the chorus remains well-known:Hey, Johnnie Cope, are ye wauking yet Or are your drums a-beating yet If ye were wauking I wad waitTae gang to the coals irsquo the morning.The song pokes fun at Cope and concludes with a harsh indictment:Now Johnnie, troth, ye were na blateTae come wirsquo news orsquo your ain defeat,And leave your men in sic a straitSae early in the morning.There are earlier versions with slightly dferent words, but the sentiment remains the same: Johnnie Cope ran away and should be ashamed of himself for leaving his men. However, he was later found to have done his duty, and this reputation deemed unfair. But mud sticks, especially when a catchy tune is added to it.This popular song is believed to have been written by Adam Skirving, a farmer at Garleton in East Lothian. There is a story that he visited the battle site a few hours after the fighting. Perhaps he spoke to some eyewitnesses who saw Cope flee up the road to Birsley Brae, and therefore got the idea for the song. The road Cope took as he fled from the battle has ever after been called Johnnie Copersquos Road.Lauder is a short journey from Prestonpansgoing by car. It had been a while since I had last ventured over Soutra Hill and into the border country and I enjoyed the drive despite the wild weather, or perhaps partly because of it.But what was Copersquos journey like as he galloped over Soutra Hill with some of his dragoons  He must have paused at the summit and cast a glance at the view over East Lothian and screwed his eyes to find Prestonpans. The panic and terror by this time would have given way to dferent feelings, I suspect.He rode more or less the same way I took to Lauder but it would have taken him much longer with very dferent emotions. His arrival in the town would have been a bewildering spectacle for the locals. He later continued his flight to Coldstream, which he reached by nightfall.All this was in my head as we headed home to Prestonpans from Lauder the next day. I could almost see the ghosts of Cope and his dragoons gallop past us as we ventured over Soutra.As we drove, I re-told the story to my kids and we sang the song in the car. They know the story and the chorus well, as we have many times ventured along Johnnie Cope Road on the way to the rail station.By the road is Bankton House, once the home of Colonel Gardiner, who did not run but stood his ground, and paid the ultimate price with brutal death.There is a small doorsquocot by the house, and inside you will find a free but almost secret visitor centre created with the support of the Battle of Prestonpans Heritage Trust.The doorsquocot can only be reached via a walkway through the wood from the rail station during the day, and inside lsquoAuld Archiersquo tells the tale of the battle, and the le and death of Colonel Gardiner. On the wall is a model map of how the area looked at the time of the battle, with the route taken by Johnnie Cope clearly marked.Itrsquos all fascinating stuff which had been unexpectedly brought to my mind by the visit to Lauder to see old friends.But it was the emotions rather than the events that I reflected on most. The hatred caused by this civil war , the loss, suffering and misery of conflict which is so often hidden by a cloak of romanticism.Adam Watters, a Panner who lives and breathes local history, and re-enacts it for children and visitors alike, is clear on this. It is a fascinating period to study, and to have the history on our doorstep brings it alive. But as Adam has said, letrsquos enjoy that sense of history on our doorstep and have fun with it, but let us not glory battle, rather learn from it.I think Johnnie Cope, even though he was a military man, may well have agreed with Adam.

title: east-lothian-council-cockenzie-revised-plan
story: Inch Cape Offshore Ltd has been given approval to site the building ndash which will bring energy ashore from an offshore wind farm ndash on land at the former Cockenzie Power Station by Scottish Ministers.A planning application was initially lodged with East Lothian Council but was called in by the Scottish Government before a decision was made.That decision sparked anger after it was announced as First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was on an official visit to China, where she met representatives of Chinese state owned Red Rock, which owns Inch Cape.Now the company has presented a revised plan of the space it intends to use to Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council.The community council posted the new design on social media and revealed plans were under way for Inch Cape to host workshops in the local communities in the coming months.The image shows the substation on about a third of the original .-hectare footprint applied for.One of the biggest concerns raised by communities and the local authority, which owns the land, was that a substation dominating the old power station site would make it a no-go area for other developments.The new plans were welcomed by many on the community councilrsquos Facebook page, with one person saying: ldquoGood news, less sterilisation of the site.Ian Johnson, Inch Capersquos project manager, said: ldquoWe are continuing to engage with East Lothian Council and local community councils on options to signicantly reduce the footprint of the onshore transmission works and moving this to the west of the site.ldquoWhile this detailed design plan is subject to further technical assessments, consultation and approval from the council, we are taking steps to ensure remaining land is available for other developments.

title: east-lothian-school-pupils-to-take-part-in-strike-against-climate-change
story: The NBHS Eco Committee have encouraged students to travel by public transport to attend the rally campaigning for stronger government action to combat climate change.The Edinburgh protest is one of many around the world that are happening tomorrow morning, where school children are walking out of classes to protest climate change.The protest starts at am outside the Scottish Parliament.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWe want to support our young people as global citizens to have their voice and to be able to express their views on important matters such as climate change."The safety and wellbeing of our young people is of paramount importance to us. We would therefore ask that any young person who wishes to attend this event first discusses it with their parent or carer before notying the headteacher of the intention to be absent from school on this date."Given that the young person will not be on school premises at this time, and therefore not the responsibility of school staff, they will be marked as having had an unauthorised absence.

title: three-hour-jumpathon-for-red-nose-day-at-musselburgh-trampoline-park
story: The team at Jump In in Newhailes Industrial Estate will need to have a real spring in their step when they don their pyjamas to take part in a national -hour Jumpathon relay with the companyrsquos seven other UK sites.Theyrsquore inviting more jumpers to join them for their three-hour session in aid of Comic Relief between pm and pm tomorrow .There will be the chance to donate on the day or those who canrsquot attend but would still like to show their support can visit justgiving fundraising jump-inGareth Trail, regional manager for Jump In, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be involved in Red Nose Day, raising money for so many special causes.ldquoWe would love to see as many people as possible down here on the day showing their support to our staff, who will be jumping for three hours non-stop.Other attractions on the day will include face-painting, a cake sale and raffle with a hamper full of Jump In goodies up for grabs.

title: cockenzie-and-port-seton-gala-saved
story: The galas organising committee had announced on Monday evening that this years gala had been cancelled due to a lack of volunteers.But an outpouring of support on social media caused an emergency meeting to be held yesterday eveningto consider the future of the gala.And following that meeting, the gala committee posted on Facebook: ldquoWe would like to give a big thank you to all who attended the EGMtonight."We are thrilled to announce that we are now in a position to go ahead with the  gala.Full steam ahead!Cockenzie and Port Seton Gala celebrated its th anniversary last year and is one of the largest galas in East Lothian.

title: tranents-redeveloped-former-co-op-building-getting-ready-to-re-open
story: The building on Winton Place is being converted into a Post Office, convenience store and coffee shop by well-known local couple George and SusanThomson.ldquoWe want to expand the business but we also want a nice place for people in the community to go and socialise, said George. ldquoWe want to draw people to the High Street.ldquoWersquove ran the Post Office in Tranent for over  years now, added Susan. ldquoWersquore really involved with the community, so this project was important to us in so many ways.As well as being postmaster, Susanco-founded the Blooming Belters and is the secretary of the townrsquos gala committee.ldquoAlthough wersquore converting a lot of it, it will still be able to host the local groups and charities that make this community so special, she said.The Thomsons worked closely with Historic Scotland to ensure that the Edwardian building retained its original charm, including putting in stained glass windows around the outside of the structure.George said: ldquoThe stained glass windows help make the building look how it would have looked a hundred years ago.ldquoHistoric Environment Scotland had also asked to have a temporary exhibition about the history of shopfronts in the country over the last  years, and there was so much interest in it that wersquove made it into a permanent display.The impressive window display covers all styles of shopfronts in Scotland throughout the century, giving information on the dferent materials used, accompanied by an archive of photos of shops dating back to the late s.ldquoThe work wersquove done with Historic Scotland is a perfect example of a public and private partnership that can maintain and renovate listed buildings, George said.The plans for the building have been in the making since  and Susanrecalled the highs and lows of taking on such project.ldquoItrsquos great finally seeing it all come together, she said. ldquoAt the start itrsquos dficult to see what it will look like and, of course, itrsquos a lot of work. Wersquore excited for it to be open and for people to get to see the finished product. We think itrsquoll be pretty special, especially in the summer when we get the chairs outside and all the flowers are in bloom.The opening in April will mark the end of phase one for the Thomsons.Phase two will involve creating a soft play area and flats above the shop, as well as a community hall.The work on phase two will begin in August, with hopes that the whole project will be completed by .

title: giant-bear-statue-could-be-in-place-near-dunbar-next-month
story: Permission for the ft-tall bear was finally given in October last year, with the work of art set to be in place in the spring.Renowned Scottish artist Andy Scott, responsible for the Kelpies, near Falkirk, has created the sculpture in tribute to Dunbar-born Muir, who went on to play a key role in the formation of the US national park system.The sculpture will be sited off the A, near to Dunbarrsquos McDonaldrsquos and Asda, and was selected by Hallhill Development Ltd.The developer has been involved in the construction of more than  houses in the south of the town and the statue has been created through the Percent for Art Scheme, which is a condition of planning consent.Ken Ross, from Hallhill Development Ltd, stressed there was not ldquoan exact date as yet but discussions were ongoing and the bear could be in place by April  ndash Muirrsquos birthday.

title: im-innocent-mp-fiona-onasanya-pleads-with-voters-to-avoid-being-unseated
story: In the clip, recorded in front of an image of a city skyline and posted on her social media channels the day before the start of a six-week recall petition, she claims she is innocent of perverting the course of justice.The Peterborough MP was found guilty by a jury at the Old Bailey and was sentenced to three months in prison.The -year-old, who was elected as a Labour MP, served just  days for lying about who was driving her car when it was caught speeding in July .She was released on February .Ms Onasanya, a solicitor, still received her pound, salary while in jail despite missing votes in the Commons.In the video, posted on Monday, she says: ldquoI am telling you I am innocent and will continue to pursue avenues to clear my name.ldquoIf you wish for me to continue as your independent Member of Parliament I am willing and able to do so but the choice is now in your hands.ldquoI would like to say I have a deep gratitude to all who have offered prayers, support and love during this dficult period of time over the past few months and also say to you all, thank you.ldquoI will continue to be your voice of change in Parliament for as long as you wish me to do so andyou do wish me to do so I can tell you I will continue to lobby Government, I will continue to fight for social justice with all of the veracity and power that I have been so far, and continue to be your voice, because you deserve nothing less.Jurors at the Old Bailey were told that she colluded with her brother Festus after her car was clocked speeding at mph in a mph zone in the village of Thorney, near Peterborough, in July .She was sent a notice of intended prosecutionto fill out, but it was sent back naming the guilty driver as Aleks Antipow, an acquaintance of her brother, who was away visiting his parents in Russia.Festus Onasanya, , from Cambridge, was jailed for  months after he admitted three counts of perverting the course of justice over speeding, including the July  incident.Sentencing them at the Old Bailey, Mr Justice Stuart-Smith said: ldquoItrsquos a tragedy that you find yourselves here and in this predicament but it is a tragedy that you have brought on yourselves.Ms Onasanya claims in the video, posted on Monday, that her defence ldquowas never put across in the media.Giving evidence at her trial, Ms Onasanya said that when she received the notice of intended prosecutionshe left it at her motherrsquos house for whoever had borrowed her car to complete, assuming she had been in London.She said that while being pursued over the NIP she suffered a relapse of multiple sclerosis and was admitted to hospital for three days, and said that when she asked her brother about the ticket he told her it was all ldquosorted.Ms Onasanya appealed against her conviction, but this was thrown out at the Royal Courts of Justice.Rejecting her challenge, Sir Brian Leveson said: ldquoIt is a tragedy that she has damaged, probably irreparably, a promising political career but there is absolutely no basis for challenging her conviction.A recall petition will be opened on Tuesday and voters will have six weeks to sign before it closes at pm on May .If it attracts the signatures of % of eligible voters, about , people, Ms Onasanya will be forced out and a by-election called.Under recall rules, Ms Onasanya will be permitted to stand for re-election.A YouGov survey conducted in January found that of more than , people polled, % thought Onasanya should resign.

title: cadbury-pulls-irresponsible-campaign-urging-children-to-dig-up-treasure
story: The chocolate firmrsquos Freddo Treasures campaign urged children to ldquograb your metal detector and go hunting for Roman riches or ldquodig up Viking silver.But the confectioner was criticised for not warning that digging without permission is illegal.The chocolate firm on Monday said it had taken down the webpage and was going to update it to ldquofocus solely on directing families to museums where existing treasures can be found.Cadburyrsquos parent company Mondelez International said the campaign had aimed to ldquoinspire families to go on everyday adventures together, not to break the law.A spokeswoman added: ldquoIt was not our intention to encourage anyone to break existing regulations regarding the discovery of new archaeological artefacts and we are grateful this matter has been brought to our attention.ldquoWe can now confirm that the webpage has been taken down and we are updating the content to focus solely on directing families to museums where existing treasures can be found.The move was welcomed by Heritage Minister Michael Ellis, who branded the campaign as ldquoirresponsible.I have been told that the irresponsible @CadburyUK #FreddoTreasures campaign has been taken down. While we want young people to explore our nations history, there are obviously rules in place under the Treasure Act to protect finds. This campaign puts that at risk.mdash Michael EllisMarch , The Northampton North MP added: ldquoThis irresponsible campaign places heritage sites and finds at risk.ldquoI am all for encouraging people to explore our nationrsquos history through our spectacular heritage sites, but we have laws in place to protect our most important archaeological sites and the Treasure Act safeguards finds so that they can be studied and preserved to benefit the public.ldquoI am pleased Cadburyrsquos have now removed this campaign from their websites and I call on them to engage with the heritage community to ensure they understand the consequences.The advertising watchdog said it had received about  complaints about the campaign.This irresponsible campaign places heritage sites and finds at risk.The Advertising Standards Authority said the general nature of the complaints was that the advert was ldquoirresponsible by encouraging ldquopotentially illegal activity such as committing trespass by accessing sites without permission, causing criminal damage by digging without permission, or by stealing objects belonging to landlords.A spokesman said it was assessing the complaints to establish whether there are any grounds for further action, but no decision had been taken.Historic England, the Governmentrsquos heritage agency, also welcomed the site being taken down.Its chief executive Duncan Wilson said: ldquoUnfortunately Cadburyrsquos PR campaign encouraging digging for treasure potentially puts people at odds with the law.ldquoThere are strict rules that protect Englandrsquos archaeological heritage, including laws governing use of metal detectors.ldquoWe are glad to see the campaign website is no longer live and would be happy to advise Cadbury to make sure any future campaign doesnrsquot have unwelcome results.

title: first-full-sized-bus-with-driverless-technology-trialled-in-uk
story: Stagecoach said the vehicle will use autonomous s to move around a depot in Manchester.The system uses multiple sensors such as radar, optical cameras and ultrasound to plan a path for the vehicle while detecting and avoiding objects.It is hoped this could provide future benefits during passenger journeys, such as providing a warning when a cyclist or pedestrian may be in a blind spot.Existing rules mean a driver must remain on board the bus at all times during the trial, although the UK is in the process of updating its regulations around driverless vehicles.The software being used in Manchester will form the basis of another pilot scheme next year involving five autonomous buses transporting passengers between Edinburgh and Fe across the Forth Road Bridge Corridor.Stagecoach chief executive Martin Grfiths said: ldquoStagecoach was the original transport disruptor, trying new things and breaking new ground, and that has never changed.ldquoThis is an exciting project to trial autonomous technology on a full-sized bus for the first time in the UK.ldquoOur employees are the beating heart of our business and I believe that will remain the case, but the world is changing fast, particularly where new technology is involved, and itrsquos our job to lead the way in looking at ways to continually progress and improve our operations for the good of the many people who use our bus services every day.

title: Scotland s Insider Guide  Banchory
story: The surrounding landscape, meanwhile, is simply spectacular, with hills and glens, forests and rivers, castles and waterfalls galore. Indeed, you can see why Her Majesty isnrsquot the only one tempted back to the area year after year.Historic highlightsSome  miles west of Aberdeen, Banchory is believed to have been founded by ldquoBishop of the Picts St Ternan, a follower of St Ninian, in the fth century.Two early Christian cross-slabs still survive on the site of the townrsquos earliest church.The Burnett of Leys family were influential in the area, having been given land by Robert the Bruce in . They built Crathes Castle in the sixteenth century, which served as the ancestral family home until , when it was given to the National Trust for Scotland.Scotlands Insider Guide: InverurieBanchory grew signicantly in the Victorian era with the coming of the railway in  . These days it remains a popular choice for families, commuters andtourists alike.What to doYoursquoll enjoy exploring Banchoryrsquos handsome, bustling streets with its attractive granite architecture, historic churches and vibrant mix of shops, cafes and hotels.A trip to the excellent Banchory Museum on Bridge Street is a must . Telling the story of Banchory and its people, it is particularly strong on the le and times of James Scott Skinner ndash the Strathspey King ndash fiddler and dancemaster to Queen Victoria. There are also fascinating exhibits on the archaeological wealth of the area and the local contribution to the First World War.Since  the Barn Arts Centrehas been the townrsquos main creative hub.With a great reputation on the folk and traditional scene, it stages regular live music, comedy and drama, as well as film screenings and visual art.Have a mooch about the on-site gallery or visit Buchananrsquos Bistro next door for coffee and cake. You can also wander round the community allotments and wild garden to the rear.The Falls of Feugh on the southern edge of town offer wonderful views all year round, but during February and March, then in September to November, you may be lucky enough to witness the extraordinary natural phenomenon of salmon leaping.Dating back to the mid-th century, historic Crathes Castle and garden is also a mustfor visitors to the town. Inside this Scots baronial masterpiece there are antiques, portraits, painted ceilings and Burnett family heirlooms galore, with some linking back to the days of Robert the Bruce.Outside, meanwhile, the stunning garden and grounds are home to a wonderful array of plants, trees and wildle.Scotlands Insider Guide: InverurieYoursquoll easily spend a whole day at this family-friendly castle, which hosts a full schedule of events throughout the year and has a smashing courtyard cafeacute.Castle open at weekends only till April , then daily. Gardens and cafeacute now open daily. Meanwhile, more adventurous visitors looking to channel their inner Tarzan will enjoy the on-site Go Ape treetop experience .Andone castle isnrsquot enough, just a -minute drive from Crathes is Drum Castle, ancient seat of clan Irvine. Also in the care of the National Trust for Scotland, it recently underwent an impressive renovation. The cosy tearoom is worth a visit in itself.Where to eatThe award-winning Cow Shedbrasserie in Raemoir Road offers local seasonal ingredients cooked with flair and simplicity in lovely surroundings.The Deeside venison with haggis olives is a delight, and the fish and chips are also world-beating, whether eaten in or bought from the Cowshed ldquochipper.The Falls of Feugh Restaurant at Bridge of Feughalso reflects the best of Scotlandrsquos larder, blending local ingredients with a modern, no-fuss approach.The rainbow trout with langoustine bisque and locally foraged wild garlic is an excellent calling card, while the steaks are memorable too.If itrsquos a taste of the Mediterranean yoursquore after, Mamma Mia in Dee Street is the place to be, run by locals Michele Rossetti and Lesia Robertson. Superb pizzas and the best tiramisu in town.The Chatterbox Cafeacute in Dee Street serves up tasty soups, sandwiches and cakes. Anditrsquos a buttery yoursquore after, yoursquove come to the right place. Tease Coffee Bar on the High Street offers an extensive choice of ethical coffee from all over the world. Full selection of teas and hot chocolates, too. And the carrot cake is sensational.Where to shopDeeside Drinks Emporium stocks a fantastic array of wines, whiskies and artisan beers with a focus on the local.Gt shop Copper  Grey on the High Street is full of bright and breezy cards, gts, stationery and jewellery.Keen cooks looking to source the best local ingredients should head to the Banchory Farmerrsquos Market from am till pm on the third Saturday of the month at Bellfield car park.Scotlands Insider Guide: InverurieFoodies will also want to visit Finzean Estate Farm Shop which sells a wide range of fresh vegetables, home-reared beef, Finzean venison and game, local artisan cheeses and home-made preserves.At nearby Milton of Crathes, Milton Art Gallery has work by local artists as well as a fine selection of prints and jewellery.Where to stayBoutique: Award-winning Banchory Lodge sits right on the banks of the Dee and offers a friendly boutique experience from pound a night. The newly renovated rooms are spacious and decadent.Traditional luxury: Four-star Tor-Na-Coille is a classic country house hotel set in beautul grounds, with sweeping views across the Aberdeenshire hills. Rooms from pound a night.Quirky: Shieling Beag is a gorgeous studio apartment for two just a few hundred yards from the town centre, with access to a private garden and wonderful views. From pound a night on AirbnbWhat to do nearbyYou donrsquot have to go far for an evocative insight into ancient Aberdeenshire. Nine Stanes Stone Circle, just three miles from Banchory, has been part of the landscape here for more than  years.The Deeside Railway was a vital transport link for over  years before being closed as part of the notorious Beeching cuts of the s.More recently the line has been revitalised by the Royal Deeside Railway Preservation Society, which offers a traditional ndash and magnicent ndash steam and diesel experience along the River Dee. Go to deeside-railway for details.Cairngorms National Park, the UKrsquos biggest, is just a short drive from Banchory, a stunning natural playground for walkers, climbers, hill runners, cyclists, kayakers, wildle-lovers and photographers of all ages and abilities.Even beach bums will be in their element thanks to the beautul sands at Loch Morlich.In the weeks to come Ill be visiting Portree, Dunkeld and Birnam, and Comrie. Email your recommendations about the best things to do and places to eat, stay and shop, to: marianne.taylor@heraldandtimes.

title: scotland-draw-with-england-after-incredible-comeback
story: Having played for  minutes against Italy, and in limited instalments against Ireland, France and Wales, Scotland went for broke as they trailed - after half an hour yesterday, to pull off an amazing comeback, almost the most incredible international victory in history, but ultimately, restore a great deal of pride in what has been a fractured campaign.All the aspirations ahead of that first game against Italy, and even after that opening Saturday victory, were slowly eroded, leaving us with just one win up until the England game to show for all the trials and tribulations this term. Still, mixing metaphors and managers, in the words of Ally MacLeod in , itrsquoll be fine once we get to the World Cup. It might well bethe final  minutes in west London was anything to pin your hopes on.With France beating Italy and Wales clinching the Grand Slam against the Irish, it effectively turned the Twickenham game in to a dead rubber. Just pride and some old forged rupees to play for. A chance for some exhibition stuff, surely  Yes, but no-one could possibly have predicted the twists and turns that would fill match time.Yesterday began with the match ball being delivered, after a bike run from Stirling to Twickers, by former Scotland captain Rob Wainwright, round the world biker Mark Beaumont, endurance cyclist Russell Ky and a few other on their latest Doddie Gump, on behalf of the My Namersquo Doddie Foundation. A worthy cause, but as England were running in tries for fun during the opening exchanges at the rate of a point per minute, a well-intentioned wrong turning somewhere in the Midlands may have been a better idea. No ball, no game.The day started badly for the Scots and deteriorated. Irsquom not a fan of the tune, but who dictates Flower of Scotland should be played in waltz-time  Take your partners for a St Bernardrsquos.For Scottish football fans, lsquorsquo means so much. Yesterday that was all it took, in seconds, for England to score. Cue lsquoSweet Chariot.rsquo Unfortunately, it was supercharged and had four-wheel drive and rumbled over the Scots in those early battles. Around this time I received a text from a mate. ldquoHeading back in to Richmond and the Orange Tree. Cannae watch this. I hope they had a telly.For when all appeared lost, from somewhere, Scotland managed to pull out a fightback of epic proportions. Guys who had looked lost, suddenly became world -beaters McInally, Maitland, Graham, Russell, Johnson and others, all of them really. We knew Scotland could play like that. We had seen it before. But given how their self-belief must have been steamrollered in that opening quarter, this effort will be written in to Scots rugby,not sporting folklore. But let us not forget how close wersquod come to an absolute disaster yesterday before salvaging self-respect and some much-needed championship points. But what, ultimately, have we achieved this far in to  Before a ball was kicked, passed or dropped in anger, I had upset one or two with my prediction that, at best, Scotland might finish fourth in this yearrsquos Six Nations. My guesstimate actually had a bit of logic behind it. Italy was a given, but we donrsquot win on the road that often, especially in Paris or London, while Ireland and Wales are quitedecent teams, but at Murrayfield, we just might ndash with a decent wind - shade it against one of them.We didnrsquot and fourth became fth, accompanied by a catalogue of excuses not turning pressure in to points, not being accurate or clinical enough, and, not having any luck when it comes to losing key personnel. Letrsquos take that point firstThere has been a steady progression at international level whereby Scotland has built strength and experience in depth, something that on reflection, really wasnrsquot there a decade back, no matter how much we may kid ourselves. However, unlike England and perhaps the French, Scotland still donrsquot have the cover or resource to accommodate a casualty count running in to double figures,not dozens.Even for the layman, the attrition rate during this championship has not gone unnoticed. Five test matches in seven weeks, particularly given the intensity of the international game today, is enough to break bodies. Good job no-one has ever been daft enough to think out loud that five successive weekend Tests could be an option in the future.However, much of Scotlandrsquos woes have been self-imposed. Compared to  months ago, when we looked to score on any play, from any position, over the last few weeks we have collectively just ran up too many blind alleys. Yes, it all fell in to place latterly against England, but be honest, on another day wersquod have been crushed and left humiliated.Instead we werenrsquot, instead we left with a touch of optimism, and instead of pain, we left with that ancient silver pot, the Calcutta Cup.Moving pictures of Scotlandrsquos last victory at Twickenham are not quite in monochrome, more a slightly washed-out colour. The video tape should last a few more years before it breaks down to dust, through age. However, after our near- disintegration yesterday, we still live with the prospect of that historic recording decaying before we win again.Better teams than the one eventually selected by Gregor Townsend have biennially headed south, more in hope than honest belief in search of that illusive victory. In two years time, at least we will travel with signicantly more optimism, evenit is  years, and counting hellip

title: paul-hutcheon-brexit-is-a-tragic-plot-line-in-a-tory-soap-opera
story: IT has become an almost a cliche to pay tribute to the Prime Ministerrsquos resilience while simultaneously deriding her lack of political nous.She is stubborn and dogged, her supporters say. She never gives up. She hung around to clear up the Brexit mess left by her awful predecessor. Only a hard heart could disagree with this analysis.Theresa May also deserves a degree of sympathy for her decision to push for a general election in . Almost every commentator, it should be recalled, believed she would rout Jeremy Corbyn and lay the path for a Brexit deal. The fault lay in the hapless campaign she led, not in the triggering of an election.Nearly two years later, May is the central character in a Westminster horror story. No matter how she rolls the dice, no majority appears to exist for any form of Brexit. She is bringing back her draft withdrawal agreement this week, but she is in need of a political miracle.This is where personal sympathy ends and political blame can rightly be aimed in her direction. May, and nobody , is the architect of a Brexit impasse that could see the UK crash out of the European Union without a deal. MPs ldquovoted against this outcome last week, but only EU member states can grant an extension to Article . The EU can name its price.Mayrsquos historic blunder was in laying out a series of Brexit ldquored lines at her partyrsquos conference in . Showing off in front of the Tory faithful, she ruled out the UK staying in either the customs union or the single market, which at a stroke necessitated the creation of the hated Northern Ireland backstop. Withdrawing the UK from the scope of the European Court of Justice - a May obsession from her days at the Home Office - was also written in blood.Her rigid approach may have drawn applause from hundreds of elderly Tories in the conference hall, but the red lines made it impossible for Labour, the SNP or the Lib Dems to support her Brexit plan. She put herself at the mercy of right-wing colleagues in European Research Group and the Democratic Unionist Party. The ideologues were given a veto.Mayrsquos mistake was in forgetting her partyrsquos history. In , John Major was challenged for the leadership by Cabinet colleague John Redwood, whose campaign was motivated by hostility to the EU. A photograph of his supporters from that period is a historical curiosity. It shows a small band of hardliners - people like the late Teddy Taylor and Teresa Gorman - who could not compromise on their loathing of the EU. This grouplet is now a large faction and is blocking Mayrsquos deal. She has allowed herself to be captured by the ERG and held hostage.Brexit is consuming the nation, but the UKrsquos departure from the EU is a tragic plot line in a Tory soap opera. David Cameron committed his party to a referendum in a bid to appease his right wing and stop the rise of UKIP. He refrained from ldquoblue on blue attacks during the campaign for fear of splitting the Conservatives. From beginning to end, Cameron was concerned about party management. May has copied this insular strategy.Her flawed approach brings two options into focus this week. The first is for her ERG tormentors to back her deal, which would be followed by a short extension to Article . Few people expect the militants to turn into eleventh-hour pragmatists. The second option is, on the back of her deal being rejected for a third time, to ask the EU for a much ier delay.Such an outcome would present a huge opportunity for a Prime Minister who was concerned with bringing the country together, rather than healing her partyrsquos wounds. With a yearrsquos breathing room, she could ditch her red lines and hurl the ERG into obscurity. If May backed either a soft Brexit, or a confirmatory vote on her deal, a majority of MPs would follow her.The last thirty years suggest that May will look inwards, not outwards. Europe brought down Thatcher, Major and Cameron. Expect the same obsession to claim a fourth scalp.

title: snp-government-sympathetic-to-fresh-round-of-european-elections
story: Prime Minister Theresa May warned MPs last week that a y delay would ldquoundoubtedly require voters going to the polls to elect MEPs.However, in a statement to this newspaper, Nicola Sturgeonrsquos Government said it was ldquoconfident elections could be delivered in Scotland and such an outcome is ldquopreferable to Mayrsquos Brexit plan.The Prime Minister faces a pivotal week in the House of Commons as she tries to persuade MPs for the third time to support the draft withdrawal agreement she negotiated with the EU.Her plan has been rejected twice, but Tory sources believe progress has been made in winning over doubters in the Conservatives and in Northern Irelandrsquos Democratic Unionist party.However,the deal is declined, a much ier delay would likely be sought, which could ultimately lead to a softer Brexit or a second referendum.Another complication is that a delay could overlap with the European elections, which are scheduled for May.The UK was expected to leave the EU at the end of this month, and thus no longer have to send MEPs to Brussels, but an Article  extension could necessitate UK-wide participation.Pro-Brexit Tories do not want to have to contest another election for the Brussels parliament, and May last week used this prospect as leverage with Conservative MPs who oppose her plan:ldquoSuch an extension would undoubtedly require the United Kingdom to hold European Parliament elections in May . I do not think that that would be the right outcome, but the House needs to face up to the consequences of the decisions that it has taken.The SNP Government, however, which supports a so-called Peoplersquos Vote, is sympathetic to the European elections taking place.A Scottish Government spokesperson said: ldquoThe Scottish Government is calling for the Article  EU withdrawal process to be extended for as long as it takes to enable a second referendum on EU membership to be held.ldquoIn those circumstances, discussions would have to take place with the EU regarding elections for the European Parliament taking place in the UK ndash and we are confident this could be delivered across Scotland.ldquoHolding an election,that was necessary, would clearly be preferable to Scotland being forced out of the EU under the damaging terms of the Prime Ministerrsquos deal or the catastrophe of a lsquono dealrsquo outcome.An SNP insider said the party would contest any poll on an anti-Brexit  and reflect the views of the majority of people north of the border.It is understood the SNPrsquos governing national executive committee has taken steps present a list of candidates, should an election take place.Keith Brown, the SNPrsquos depute leader, said: "Theresa May has made such a hash of Brexit, we started preparations in January. So wersquore all fired up, ready to go."The Scottish Liberal Democrats, another anti-Brexit party, are also in a position to pick candidatesan election arises.Scottish Labour are waiting to seeArticle  is extended before making a decision, while a spokesperson for the Scottish Tories said their ldquoexpectation is that Mayrsquos deal will pass, and so no preparations are being made.Documents circulating among EU ambassadors state the bloc would terminate the UKs membership on July stit has not taken part in European Parliament elections.The draft paper makes clear Britain has to take part in the electionsit wants an extension of more than three months.Meanwhile, May is continuing her efforts to salvage her Brexit deal amid further signs of pressure on her position.Further talks are expected over the coming days with the DUP in the hope that persuading the  Northern Irish MPs to back the deal will help sway scores of Tory Eurosceptics to fall into line.DUP deputy leader Nigel Dodds said y talks on Friday with senior ministers including Chancellor Philip Hammond were "constructive" and there was a "renewed focus" from the Government on addressing their concerns.Dodds said: "We have had a constructive dialogue. Those discussions will continue over the coming period of time."Former Cabinet minister Esther McVey suggested fellow Brexiteers could back Mays "rubbish" deal next week to make sure the UK leaves the EU.She told the BBC: "The element now is that people will have to take a bad deal rather than no deal."It has also emerged that senior Tory MP Nick Boles has quit his local Conservative Association in the face of efforts to deselect him as the candidate for the next election amid rows over Brexit.The former minister, who supports a soft Brexit, told members of Grantham and Stamford Conservative Association he was resigning "with immediate effect" but will continue to "take the Conservative whip at Westminsterit is offered "on acceptable terms", according to a letter.Councillor Martin Hill, vice president of the Grantham and Stamford Conservative Association, told members: "As you are all aware, Nick has been at odds with the local party and the Prime Minister for some time, so this announcement does not come as a complete surprise, but the timing does leave at lot to be desired.Chief Whip Julian Smith said Mr Boles "is a valued member of the Conservative Parliamentary party which I hope will continue to benefit from his ideas and drive".

title: destination-detox-13-of-scotlands-coolest-spas
story: Wersquove put together our list of  coolest spas, so you can choose just where to treat your mum, yourself, or anyone  in need of a proper unwind. Stobo Castle,PeeblesThe fact this spa is located in a castle that has its own helipad speaks volumes about the kind of luxury experience it offers. Last year, this Borders-based hotel was crowned best destination spa at the Good Spa Guide awards.The range of treatments is extensive, including the Neom collection which uses aromatherapy to enhance treatments. The ozone-treated swimming pool is a dream and looks out through giant windows on to the hillside beyond.Buta bit more privacy is what you want, therersquos always a lounge in the private hot tubs, away from it all. Even the ladies loos have their own special technological experience.Spa Day packages start with the pound Relaxing Spa Day, which includes water massage, express facial and lunch. Auchrannie Resort,Brodick, ArranArranrsquos top-notch Auchrannie Resort has an indulgence for everyone ndash even offering a Princess Package in the spa for children. With two swimming pools, a games hall and an adventure activity programme, there is also plenty to distract the kids.Treatments revolve around Espa products and Ishga, a range made from Scottish seaweed harvested in the Outer Hebrides. Stayyou can in one of the woodland lodges, where you can relax in your own wood-fired hot tub while taking in a view of the glen.Packages include Island Escape, offering two -minute treatments at pound, and Island Retreat ndash pound for two -minute treatments selected from a range including full body massage, algae wrap, luxury manicure or pedicure, and signature facial. Dunkeld House Hotel,DunkeldSet in  acres of private grounds in Perthshire, on the banks of the river Tay, Dunkeld House is all about the relaxation with its sauna, steam room, whirlpool bath and heated indoor pool surrounded by views over the Craigvinean Hills.The spa specialises in treatments using products by the Scottish organic seaweed skincare brand, Ishga. Special offer during March is the Made For Le Mindful Moments treatment, priced at pound for  minutes of ldquonurturing meditation combined with ldquofoot ritual, head, neck and shoulder massage, and back massage. Principal Blythswood Square Hotel, GlasgowSpa of the year at The Look Awards , the Principal Blythswood Square Hotel is the destination spa in Glasgow. In the basement of one of Scotlandrsquos most swish hotels it is a hidden gem, complete with hydrotherapy pool, sauna and crystal steam room.If therersquos a treatment you want, itrsquos likely you can get it here ndash from hot stone massages to revitalising body scrubs, and with names to make you swoon even before yoursquove got your robe and slippers on. Among them are Ila Pearl and Jasmine Amethyst Wrap, Ila Rose Bliss Bath or Twilight Thermal Experience. Plus the whole look of the place is to die for ndash black tiles, white spaces, chill relaxation areas.This is for those who can only chill out in the trendiest, most style-forward of environments. Pure, Apex Hotel,#EdinburghRight in the centre of Edinburgh, on the edge of the Old Town, Pure spa has a joint in the Apex hotel, and while itrsquos not huge, itrsquos got everything you might want for a bit of indulgence while enjoying the delights of the capital. It specialises in Elemis anti-ageing facials, as well as heat therapies, massages and scrubs.Its one of a growing chain of Pure spas to be found across the UK.  SVS,GlasgowYou donrsquot get much more stylish than this Art Deco spa on St Vincent Street, right in the heart of Glasgow. Itrsquos the perfect pamper stop-off on a city day out.Treatments are based around Elemis products, aromatherapy and Opi and Shellac manicure.Here you can also try Hopi ear candling or get some party strip lashes done to get you set for a night out on the town. Stables spa,Isle of EriskaOn a small, private island at the mouth of Loch Creran, attached to a Scottish baronial-style house, is the Stables spa, complete with -metre swimming pool, reached by a path through the spa garden. If what you want is proper indulgence then book one of the one-bedroom spa suites and Hilltop Reserve villas with their own hot tubs. The spa offers, it says, ldquofive treatment rooms, three to connect you to the natural land, plants and wood, and two connecting you to the cleansing sea and tranquil shores that surrounds you.Spa day packages include the Rasul Experience ndash pound to sit in your own private mud chamber ndash and the Discover Eriska Spa Package, which includes two -minute treatments and afternoon tea for pound. Portavadie,Loch FyneThe Portavadie development has transformed this not-so-easy-to-reach spot on Loch Fyne into a top destination ndash and the star of it all is the spa, which not only offers a hydro pool, sauna, steam room and a bunch of treatments, but also a stunning heated outdoor infinity pool, the largest in Scotland, that looks out over the loch.The views are part of the thrill even in the sauna and relaxation space, where floor-to-ceiling windows look out on it all ndash you might possibly catch sight of a seal or an otter as you relax. Portavadie has even earned a Green Tourism Gold Award for its use of renewable energies throughout the resort. Day packages include the Harmony Retreat at pound, which includes an Ishga or Decleor treatment. New Lanark Hotel,New Lanark villageOriginally an th-century cotton mill and placed right in the middle of the New Lanark World Heritage site, the New Lanark Hotel offers a spa day that is like chilling in a piece of history. The New Lanark Health and Fitness Club includes a swimming pool, Jacuzzi, steam room, sauna and a health and fitness studio, plus beauty rooms for guests to enjoy a range of customised treatments including candle massage, aromatherapy massage, waxing treatments, manicures and pedicures.Spa day packages available at pound., and residential spa packages from pound per person, including dinner, bed and breakfast and use of the spa. One Spa, Sheraton Grand,EdinburghIf you thought city spas were small and bijou, think again. One Spa is a huge, therapeutic sprawl of  treatment rooms, a -metre pool, relaxation area, steam rooms, saunas and rooftop hydrotherapy pool. All of this on the edge of the city centre, overlooking Edinburgh Castle. It even offers, through the Now By One Spa, express experiences targeting the time-poor, stressed-out urbanite. But the best way to experience it is on a long day package, darting from sauna to pool to chill-out area.The Revival Spa Day , for instance, includes a body massage and facial, plus use of spa for pound. Knock Castle spa,CrieffIn the town of Crieff in rural Perthshire, Knock Castle is a boutique hotel, quirky enough to have its own grand piano in the hallway and offering its own distinct luxury spa experience. Among its pleasures is its heated swimming pool, surrounded by large windows which look out on to the gardens around. But there is also the steam room, the sauna and The Egg, a stress-busting chamber, which was developed by an Aberdeen firm. Inside this eight feet-tall pod, you lie on a contoured massage bed and thus begins a multisensory treatment of lighting, sounds and aromatherapy.Knock Castle also offers a range of treatments, including the Chocolate Experience ndash a -minute massage and paraffin wax treatment, at pound.
