title: parents-of-a-girl-with-downs-syndrome-say-they-lives-are-enriched
story: ROSIE is busy in the living room, playing on her tablet. Shersquos blissfully unaware of the conversation her parents are having at the kitchen table.The dresser behind Jamie and Victoria McCallum is filled with dozens of birthday cards from Rosiersquos classmates. Shersquos just turned six - but the couple are discussing what le would have been liketheyrsquod terminated the pregnancy. Rosie was born with Downrsquos Syndrome.The McCallums didnrsquot have to confront the idea of termination, however, while Victoria was pregnant. They didnrsquot take any tests. It was only when Rosie was born that they realised she had Downrsquos Syndrome. Victoria wouldnrsquot have terminated, eventests had come back positive. Jamie, though, knowing nothing about the condition then, might have thought dferently.lsquoWe wouldrsquove had a hell of a debate on our hands,rsquo he says. Victoria wonders aloud lsquowhether our relationship would have survivedrsquo. Itrsquos impossible to quanty the joy theyrsquod have lostthere was no Rosie in their lives. Today, knowing the facts about Downrsquos Syndrome, termination would never cross Jamiersquos mind.The McCallums have grown from a family devastated by Downrsquos Syndrome to one enriched by the condition. Jamie, , runs his own management consultancy, and Victoria, , worked in marketing but now raises their children at home. Theyrsquore among the most prominent advocates in Scotlandrsquos Downrsquos Syndrome community, and Rosie is something of a superstar within that world, a child who can count Michael Bubleacute, the singer Christina Perri, and Phillip Schofield and Holly Willoughby among her admirers.Those birthday cards on the dresser - from  children across their home town, Prestwick - tell the story of the changing nature of Downrsquos Syndrome within society. Years ago, there would have been no cards from friends.Every family touched by the condition shudders when they think of the past - of times like the s when children were locked away in institutions, their le chances little more than zero. Today, children with Downrsquos Syndrome are increasingly embraced by society, they look forward to a future where they go to mainstream school, get a job, live independently and fall in love. There are young people with Downrsquos Syndrome embarking on careers in theatre and sport Karen Gaffney, one of the worldrsquos best known people with Downrsquos Syndrome, swam the channel, earned an honorary doctorate, and gave a Ted talk.On Thursday itrsquos the McCallums th wedding anniversary . lsquoClearly le had a path for us,rsquo says Victoria. The family have a message to share, on this week which means so much to them. They fear that just as people with Downrsquos Syndrome are becoming accepted by mainstream society, that they may - in Jamiersquos words - soon be lsquoeradicatedrsquo.Until now, accurate testing for Downrsquos Syndrome centred on an amniocentesis, where a needle draws fluid from the uterus for analysis. Some parents are reluctant to take the test, fearing miscarriage. Now, a new blood test is to be rolled out which can accurately check for Downrsquos Syndrome without risk. The take up is expected to be huge, and the resulting terminations equally high. At the moment, the abortion rate is around  per cent. Scotland has a population of , with  births a year.lsquoIceland rolled [the new testing] out and there hasnrsquot been a Downrsquos Syndrome birth since,rsquo says Jamie. lsquoItrsquos like a government-funded eugenics programme.rsquoThe thought of a world without Rosies horries the McCallums. Both admit to being completely uninformed when Rosie - the middle of their three children - was born. Itrsquos impossible to make an informed choice about termination when all parents know are the long-standing myths - that children wonrsquot be able to dress themselves, or go to the toilet that theyrsquoll be le-long lsquoburdensrsquo, or incapable of learning.Jamie says his view of Downrsquos Syndrome when he was growing up was lsquoa form of prejudice - and prejudice comes from ignorancersquo. He would have seen lsquosomeone who canrsquot possibly be happy as they donrsquot have the faculties of the rest of us, and thatrsquos why itrsquos such a shake-up to your value system when you realise wersquove made all that stuff uprsquo.Victoria is brutally honest but even she struggles to admit that when she was growing up she probably saw people with Downrsquos Syndrome as lsquoretardedrsquo. lsquoThatrsquos a really awful thing to say,rsquo she adds. lsquoI remember feeling sorry for them. They werenrsquot accepted, they always stood on the periphery hellip When I fell pregnant one of my biggest fears was Downrsquos Syndrome.rsquoNevertheless, like many parents, they didnrsquot opt for an amniocentesis as they werenrsquot high risk. It wasnrsquot until moments after Rosiersquos birth that they realised she had Downrsquos Syndrome.lsquoI was shit scared,rsquo says Victoria. She looked at her babyrsquos eyes and lsquojust knewrsquo. Jamie was oblivious. He was holding Rosie - lsquoproud as punchrsquo - and had no idea anything was wrong until Victoria askedhe thought she had Downrsquos Syndrome. Jamie put Rosie down, took his phone to the bathroom and looked for lsquobabies with Downrsquos Syndromersquo on Google images.lsquoI knew at that point,rsquo Jamie says, but his words falter as tears overcome him. Victoria becomes upset at Jamiersquos distress and explains: lsquoItrsquos a post traumatic stress thing. It was a brutal experience.rsquoJamie continues: lsquoI just put her down and I didnrsquot pick her up again for quite some time.rsquo Victoria adds: lsquoI shut off and went into automatic mother mode. I just went lsquoI canrsquot cope with this so what I need to do is look after this babyrsquo - and Irsquod basically say lsquothis thingrsquo as at that time thatrsquos how I felt. Itrsquos brutal but itrsquos true.rsquolsquoYoursquove this path in your mind,rsquo says Jamie, lsquoand all of a sudden your entire future gets reformed - and then pour in all your prejudice, ignorance and misconceptions.rsquoVictoria was so traumatised after the birth that she couldnrsquot go to a maternity ward to visit her best friend and baby. Jamie went but lsquoa feeling of dread descended on me. You see things, like the number on the door, and itrsquos like flashbacksrsquo.The McCallums kept each other afloat those first few months - when one was down, the other was up. Victoria recalls crying as she breastfed Rosie and wonderingshe was in the middle of a lsquogrief cyclersquo and lsquoletting go of the child I expected to haversquo.She spent lsquothe first eight weeks of Rosiersquos le trying to figure outI wanted to keep herrsquo. Victoriarsquos voice falters and her eyes fill as she talks about how her sisters find that hard to believe because she was so protective of Rosie lsquofrom the moment she was bornrsquo.At one point, Jamie tried to rationalise what had happened by thinking of Rosie as a pet. Theyrsquore both shocked at the thoughts which went through their minds.Unlike many children with Downrsquos Syndrome, Rosie had no severe health problems, such as a congenital heart condition, so there was little dference raising Rosie to any other baby.Slowly, the couple began to think lsquowait a minute, why is this meant to be so bad rsquo. There was lsquono Hollywood momentrsquo, says Jamie, when things went from dark to light, but he recalls feeding Rosie one day when she was six months and apologising to her aloud. lsquoAt that point I believed it would be okay,rsquo he says, lsquoand thatrsquos a major hurdlersquo.Things changed for Victoria when she thought about adoption, but couldnrsquot imagine anyone caring for Rosie the way she could. She recalls going to a Downrsquos Syndrome meeting and realising lsquoI just want to be her mumrsquo.The mundane reality is that le with Downrsquos Syndrome just takes a little bit longer. Children will learn to read, walk, talk, go to the toilet, feed themselves - just like any other child - but theyrsquoll always be a little slower. Rosie is probably a year behind other children.Children with Downrsquos Syndrome learn dferently too. Theyrsquore more perceptive of emotions, and visual learners, says Jamie, so they identy the physical shapes of words quicker than sounds - thatrsquos why their house is plastered with stickers on furniture and appliances marked lsquoovenrsquo, lsquotable, lsquochairrsquo. They also use sign language to speed up Rosiersquos acquisition of speech.Rosie is in pre-school and about to go into Primary One. Children like her in mainstream education help eliminate prejudice. Unlike their parents, the children in Rosiersquos class have grown up with a friend with Downrsquos Syndrome and are basically blind to her condition. lsquoI can see the positive effects of Rosie on other people,rsquo says Jamie.Hersquos jealous of Rosiersquos classmates. lsquoWersquove created a society that values material things - cars, money - and these kids will grow up with someone who isnrsquot driven by that, and lives in the now, all the time, and her driving force is to be happy.rsquoVictoria adds: lsquoPeople say itrsquos changed their way of thinking, just being part of her le. She teaches us more than we could ever teach her. She teaches us to be far, far better human beings, and just be happier people.rsquoRosie and a bunch of other children with Downrsquos Syndrome touched the world this time last year when a viral video of the kids and their mums lip-synching and hand-signing a carpool karaoke version of Christina Perrirsquos lsquoA Thousand Yearsrsquo clocked  million views. Perri contacted them saying shersquod cried over the film - her song ed to the top five. It made national news in  countries, and Victoria and other mums appeared on This Morning. Michael Bubleacute got involved when the children covered lsquoAll I want for Christmasrsquo. The McCallums started the charity lsquoWouldnrsquot Change A Thingrsquo, celebrating children like Rosie, and aimed at correcting those misconceptions which caused them so much grief when she was born.Jamie says in the past hersquos told people that Downrsquos Syndrome lsquoisnrsquot as bad as you think, but now Irsquove actually come to believe that therersquos serious benefits to this - like the effect on others, like the positive effect on your own values. It makes you a better personrsquo.lsquoThe paradox is,rsquo adds Jamie, lsquothat therersquos been this major progress in understanding how they learn, major medical progress too, and thatrsquos happening simultaneously with the progress in screening and termination to the point of almost eradication. So just as yoursquove kind of cracked it on one side, therersquoll be none of them left.rsquoThe idea of there one day being no more people with Downrsquos Syndrome chills them, thinking of what would be lost. lsquoYou see beyond peoplersquos disabilities to the soul behind that, you see the person,rsquo says Victoria. lsquoThatrsquos what Rosie has taught me.rsquoJamie and Victoria treat Rosie no dferently to their other children, Abigail and Gregor - and she can get in just as much trouble as them. The McCallums expect a full le for Rosie - job, travel, love.lsquoWhen we first had Rosie,rsquo says Victoria, lsquoI was very scared that wersquod have her for the rest of our lives, but actually Rosiersquos biggest problem about leaving this house is going to be me not wanting her to go. I think the first child out the door will be her - shersquos the most independent. Irsquom not scared for her future now in any way whatsoever.rsquoWHEN WORDS CUT AS DEEP AS WOUNDSWHILE so much has changed for the better in society when it comes to the lives of people with Downrsquos Syndrome, language is still a blight. Words hurt.Jo Hughes helps run the charity Downrsquos Syndrome Scotland . It may surprise some, she says, but lsquoyou still hear people with Downrsquos Syndrome referred to as mongolsrsquo.Mistakes are also made by people not meaning to be cruel. Often the terms lsquoDownrsquos Syndrome personrsquo or a lsquoDownrsquos personrsquo is used - thatrsquos putting the disability before the human being. DSS has started a new lsquoMind Your Languagersquo campaign for Downrsquos Syndrome Week to let people know that the accepted term is lsquoa person with Downrsquos Syndromersquo.While years ago, negative misconceptions hurt, today seemingly positive misconceptions can do damage too. lsquoTherersquos a huge misconception out there that all people with Downrsquos Syndrome are forever smiley and happy,rsquo says Hughes, who worries about this lsquochildlikersquo image being thrust on the entire community. lsquoThey have the same range of emotions and feelings as every other human being.rsquo They go through puberty just like other teenagers, and can be stroppy adolescents.For Hughes, the struggle to change language is personal. Her son Jack, , has Downrsquos Syndrome and she wants him to enjoy lsquothe best le he can haversquo.Changing language, changes how people are seen, she says. lsquoFor every person who we can change how they think and talk about Downrsquos Syndrome, thatrsquos another day thatrsquos been worth going to work.rsquoSTUDENT AND SWIMMING CHAMP - JUST AN AVERAGE GIRL FROM AYRCERYS McCrindle is the future. Aged just , shersquos getting ready to leave mainstream school in Ayr after taking her National Fours in English, Maths, French, Art, Home Economics and Admin. She plans to go on to sixth year and then study beauty therapy at college.But working professionally in swimming is her real ambition. Three years ago, she joined the GB team for people with Downrsquos Syndrome, and has so far won three silvers at the Special Olympics, gold and silver at the European Championships, and bronze at the world championships.Cerysrsquo success fills her mother Karen, father Ewan and brother Lewis with pride. lsquoWersquove treated Cerys just the same as any other child since she was born,rsquo says Karen. The world is more accepting these days, but there can still be some stupid comments at school - usually from boys. Cerys lsquotells them to grow up and answers them backrsquo, her mother says. Closed minds are a minority among young people, though, and school has been a positive experience.What worries Karen most is that while the younger generation has changed, the older generation retains old-fashioned prejudices - and that might damage Cerys when it comes to employment.lsquoWersquore now coming out of the comfort zone,rsquo says Karen, adding: lsquoShersquos getting to leaving school age. Evenshe does have a full CV, is there someone whorsquod look and think lsquoDownrsquos Syndrome, whatrsquos she going to offerrsquo hellip Therersquos a fear that no-one will give her a chance.rsquo

title: one-visitor-set-aside-15m-for-a-three-day-highlands-tour
story: Scotlandrsquos new breed of high-rolling visitors may be here on holiday but most of us wonrsquot see them ndash for these are not your typical Royal Mile tourists.Instead, some of the worldrsquos wealthiest people are pouring millions into hiring castles to stay in, chartering yachts and helicopters to whisk them from distilleries to golf courses, and private dinners with lairds and lords demanding unique experiences that, it turns out, money really can buy.Scotland is in the midst of a luxury holiday boom, and attracting rising numbers of enormously wealthy visitors desperate to indulge in adventures that most Scots would never imagine.The sums of money involved can be eye-watering. One case Chinese visitor is said to have set aside pound. million for a three-day tour of the Highlands.While that is at the extreme end of the scale, insiders say itrsquos not unusual for ldquoaverage visitors to spend pound, per person for a week, while others can easily spend double that on a single shopping spree at the House of Bruar.One luxury tour operator said: ldquoThe sky is the limit. A lot of whatrsquos going on is very discreet ndash most people donrsquot realise the amount of money flowing through the country.In many cases the millionaire tourist is looking to pay top dollar to share a dram with a whisky expert, play golf on a remote Hebridean course that most Scots have never heard of, or join scallop ers and fishermen off the west coast, rather than rub shoulders with the hoi polloi at the usual tourist haunts.According to a report from Allied Market Research, the global luxury market is projected to be the fastest-growing area of the tourism sector, expected to be worth ,bn by .A key element is said to be demand from high-end travellers to gain deeper experiences of the places they visit, avoiding tourist hotspots in favour of highly-personalised trips.VisitScotland has suggested income from ldquohigh-net-worth iniduals is forecast to rise by around % a year. Chief executive Malcolm Roughead said: ldquoIt is important that we encourage the tourism industry to provide world-class service, facilities, events and attractions to keep up with ever-changing consumer demands and ensure visitors continue to have memorable experiences.While luxury tour operators have always had a place in Scotlandrsquos tourist sector, there are signs of a growing response to rising demand, from hotels offering bespoke packages, to firms specialising in personalised itineraries and road trip specialists who send tourists off in Aston Martins to tackle the North Coast  ndash at around pound, a pop.Last week, five-star Edinburgh hotel The Glasshouse became the latest to join the luxury ldquoexperience market with a two-night Elite Whisky Experience ndash costing pound, a head.That buys two nights for two people at the hotelrsquos lavish Islay Suite overlooking Calton Hill, meals ndash including a seven-course whisky tasting dinner ndash guided tour of a distillery and the chance to explore the hotelrsquos selection of  whiskies with its whisky ambassador on hand to help with selections.One company, Bravo Whisky Golf, which specialises in tailor-made golf packages which whisk visitors from course to course by chartered plane, is offering three nights in an Islay hotel and chartered plane to watch this yearrsquos Open at Royal Portrush, plus a distillery tour and a round at Machrie Golf Links ndash for around pound,.ldquoTypically, clients will spend , to , per head for golf, accommodation, flights, meals and drinks, said Neil Scott Johnson, who co-founded Bravo Whisky Golf with his friend Paul Geddes. ldquoThese people have done Carnoustie, St Andrews and Turnberry and are looking for new experiences. They want to get home and say lsquoThe plane landed on this island beach and we played an amazing Old Tom Morris links coursersquo.Among its tours is a -day ldquoOdyssey involving  flights and  golf courses ndash mostly on Hebridean islands or in the Highlands. Thrown in is dinner with a whisky aficionado and an evening on board the former royal yacht Britannia.Wealthy visitors swoop into the country on board private jets and book up entire country houses or castles for their party at eye-watering costs, says Simeon Rosset, who runs Rosset Bespoke Butlers and is often called on to arrange high-end accommodation and staff for well-heeled visitors.ldquoYou would never recognise them ndash theyrsquore not travelling around in Rolls-Royces, theyrsquore not that obvious. But they will go out on shopping trips to the House of Bruar and spend pound,, he said. ldquoTherersquos huge money travelling through Scotland. A group of  staying for a week can easily spend poundm.If anything, he adds, there is a shortage of luxury produce for them to spend their money on. ldquoThis is high-level tourism and we need to persuade people to join in and provide what they want, he said.Specialist companies like Edinburgh-based Dream Escape promise ldquoluxurious private cruises to exclusive access to historic castles and other elegant accommodation combined with Michelin-star dining, with chauffeur-driven tours, adventure activities and private helicopters.However, as well as the established players and the London-based high-end agencies, a new breed of ldquograss-roots operators is also finding a niche within a massively wealthy market.Chris Hunter of Luxury Concierge Scotland was running a chauffeur business when he spotted demand from wealthy visitors seeking ldquosomething dferent.He now organises bespoke tours, arranging castle accommodation, supercars for hitting the North Coast  and gourmet dining.ldquoI have a couple coming in June who want to tour in a car, so Irsquom organising a Porsche  for them. They want to stay in a castle on the west coast, and then therersquos the obligatory helicopter tour, so theyrsquoll go from the castle over to Skye for a distillery visit, he said.ldquoThese are people who can do spas and luxury hotels anywhere. What they want in Scotland are those experiences they canrsquot get anywhere .French-born Solveig Kerdranvat and her fianceacute Jonny Stage are the modern face of luxury travel in Scotland ndash images on their Sandgrouse website show her posing in a kilt gazing at island moorland, or ldquohunting-shooting style beside a Land Rover.The helicopter they use to ferry their clients on ldquodistillery crawls ndash involving stops at multiple distilleries across Scotland in a single day ndash features a familiar registration, G-TRMP, and was once used by Donald Trump.Sandgrouse tours can hit pound, per person, while some special requests can prove particularly demanding.ldquoPeople are looking out-of-the-box experiences, says Mr Stage. ldquoFor example, we take them to the Glenfinnan viaduct at just the right time to see the steam train passing. So theyrsquore hovering above it rather than standing in the car park with everyone .Wealthy tourists want to be able to impress their friends by doing something unique, he adds.ldquoThey want to come to Scotland and be best buddies with the fishermen on the west coast, or have a great day ing for scallops or with a ghillie whorsquos been on an estate for  years.ldquoThen they go back to New York and talk about an amazing day with a guy on the hill who showed them the stags.ldquoThatrsquos what luxury travel is about.TIE PIECEA recovering global economy is fuelling a worldwide luxury travel sector currently said to be worth  billionn.However, Scotland is hardly a new destination for the worldrsquos super rich ndash after all, the Queen made a point of spending her summer break cruising the west coast in Britannia and staying at Balmoral, while Skibo Castle near Dornoch has been a retreat for the rich for decades.Two years ago, Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich took a west coast break when he moored his super yacht, Eclipse, in the Clyde.Last year, billionaire mathematician James Simons parked his pound million super yacht at ious locations during a summer tour of Scotland. His net worth is estimated at poundbn.Meanwhile, some of the richest people in the world have opted to create a more permanent holiday home.The billionaire ruler of Dubai, Sheikh Mohammed Bin Rashid al-Maktoum, has taken over a ,-acre holiday estate in Inverinate, Wester Ross, and Russian drinks billionaire Yuri Shefler bought Tulchan Estate ndash a ,-acre property  miles south of Inverness said to boast some of the best salmon fishing in Europe.

title: former-yes-chief-indyref2-coming-down-the-track
story: Blair Jenkins, a former head of news at BBC Scotland who became the chief executive of Yes Scotland, warned his old employerto get ready for ldquoReferendum .Last time, some BBC staff ldquowere on a mission to undermine the Yes campaign, he said.Mr Jenkins was weighing into the row over BBC bias ahead of the first independence vote which has been kicked off by a new TV documentary about the referendum.Alan Little, who led the BBCrsquos referendum coverage, told lsquoInside the Indyrefrsquo some of his colleagues assumed the Yes side was ldquowrong and thought it was their job to undermine it.:BBC in bias row after senior journalist criticises colleagues over indyref coverageHe said: ldquoSome of my colleagues, by no means all, not even the majority, but some of my colleagues, who thought that our responsibility was to produce a series of pieces that would demonstrate how foolish it would be to vote Yes.Speaking to BBC Sunday Politics Scotland, Mr Jenkins backed up Mr Littlersquos account.He said Mr Little had done a ldquogreat service with a nuanced take on the referendum - painting the BBC as neither systemically biased nor blameless - and that the problems he had identied ldquowould certainly echo my own experience.Mr Jenkins said: ldquoThere were BBC Scotland people saying to me that some of the people coming up from London were on a mission to undermine the Yes campaign in the final days.ldquoI think it is important that Alan has come out and said what he has because, you know, probably another independence referendum is coming down the track.ldquoI think itrsquos going to be really important for the BBC to learn from the first referendum experience, be better prepared for Referendum ,you like, than they were first time around and take more seriously the problems they would have.He said the BBC failed to reconcile the conflict between being an impartial news provider and ldquothe chief global cheerleader of all things to do with Britain and Britishness.:Question Time row: BBC reject accusations of bias after backlash over UKIP candidateHe said: ldquoI said to someone in the BBC before I knew I would be involved in the [Yes] campaign that I thought perhaps it might be the biggest editorial challenge theyrsquod ever faced, because the future of the BBC itself was so bound up in the result.ldquoIt was very obvious that some of the correspondents parachuted into the final  days of the campaign really were struggling to catch up with the debate here. That was felt by BBC Scotland journalists, not just people external to the BBC. In a sense, the view in London was, lsquoThe only way Yes could possibly be winning is because BBC Scotland isnrsquot doing its job properly. Letrsquos send up the heavyweights and theyrsquoll sort it all outrsquo.Reacting to Mr Littlersquos comments, SNP depute leader Keith Brown said: ldquoThis is a welcome, important and courageous admission by a former senior BBC correspondent, with long experience of covering stories around the globe, that the corporation made serious mistakes in the way it covered the  referendum.":Mark Smith: Of course the BBC is biased, but the bias of the switch-off campaigners is much worseKen MacQuarrie, controller of BBC Scotland during the referendum, defended the corporations journalism in the programme.He said: ldquoClearly people would come from their own perspective, possibly with their own thoughts but I felt that these were left behind, that people were doing a professional job as far as was possible, in every situation that they came across."Mr Jenkins told BBC Sunday Politics that his private polling had put Yes ahead for several weeks before September , but this was kept it a tightly guarded secret, in case it prompted the UK Government to make a new offer on devolution.But a newspaper poll  days before the vote putting Yes ahead ldquolet the cat out of the bag.

title: cable-bows-out-saying-libdems-heading-back-to-power
story: He also told delegates in York to keep fighting to remain in the EU.Sir Vince, who retires in May, said local elections in England the same month offered a chance to rebuild after the bruising losses that followed the Coalition with the Tories.He said: ldquoThis yearrsquos local elections must be the place where we finally shake off the set-back of two damaging general elections, and regain confidence, building on the advances of the last year. We can and will.ldquoThe environment in which we do so has now changed. We are seeing early signs of some realignment. The breakaway group of independent MPs is a sign of that.ldquoI have been very clear that we must welcome a realignment of British politics and the opportunities it presents.ldquoI have also been clear that we should offer the hand of friendship to those who want to work with us rather than against us.The Independent Group of disaffected former Labour and Tory MPs has  members in Westminster, the same number as the LibDems, posing a threat to the established party.Sir Vince admitted the TIG, which wants to become a party and fight elections, would be chasing LibDem votes, but he added: ldquoThe new group has a following wind from people who are curious about something new, and who admire their decision to break with their parties. There is nothing yet beyond Westminster.ldquoNo local infrastructure. No local base. They are very exposed to a wipe-out in an early election. We arenrsquot.Referring to former leader Tim Farronrsquos description of the party as ldquocockroaches which would survive a nuclear war, Sir Vince said: ldquoI think we can do more than survive.He added: ldquoIf, as I sense, the two old, tired and increasingly discredited major parties are to fracture, we shall move forward not in small steps, but in leaps and bounds.On Brexit and a Peoplersquos Vote, Sir Vince said: ldquoI remain astounded that some people claim a new referendum would be undemocratic. What is democracyit is not the right for a country to change its mind Showing age has not mellowed him, the -year-old was fiercely critical of Theresa May and her hapless Northern Ireland Secretary Karen Bradley.He said the government was ldquoso lacking in talent it had an NI Secretary who didnrsquot know about sectarian voting and had a ldquonaively one-sided view of the killings in the Troubles, a dig at Ms Bradley saying killings by security forces were ldquonot crimes.He said: ldquoMs Bradley has revealed an ugly truth: that peace in Ireland matters less than peace in the Conservative Party.

title: call-for-review-of-key-test-on-tougher-sentences
story: The Scottish Tories want the Scottish Law Commission to review whether the undue leniency test is fit for purpose or ldquooverly restrictive and an obstacle to justice.If follows the case of -year-old dental student Daniel from Glasgow.In January, he was granted an ldquoabsolute discharge despite being found guilty of repeatedly sexually assaulting a six-year-old girl.It meant he walked out of court a free man with no criminal record.Sherf Gerald Sinclair said Daniel was motivated by ldquoinappropriate curiosity not sexual gratication, and the girl ldquoappeared to have suffered no injury or long lasting effects.The case led to calls for the Scottish Sentencing Council to update the guidelines on sexual assault.Now Tory justice spokesman Liam Kerr has said the problem lies with the test which must be met before the Crown Office can appeal a sentence it considers overly lenient.He said the Lord Advocate, James Wolffe QC, wrote to him in February saying the Crown could only apply for a longer sentencethe first was unduly lenient, with the definition of unduly lenient dating from .In a letter to Mr Yousaf, Mr Kerr said he understood the importance of legal precedent but added ldquoeverything can be improved and often must be to maintain public confidence.He said Mr Yousaf should ask the Scottish Law Commission, the body which recommends improvements in Scots law to the Government, to review the unduly leniency test and ldquoassure itself and the public it is operating as intended and in accordance with the principles of justice.He added: ldquoWhen a convicted child abuser walks free from court with no punishment, not even a criminal record, the system has failed.ldquoThe Crown Office may have been restricted by the test of lsquoundue leniencyrsquo so the Scottish Law Commission must review this test to ensure this is not the case.ldquoWhile this outcome has been utterly devastating for the victim and her family, we must, at least try to ensure that no one  is treated in this appalling way.The Scottish Government said: ldquoWe have supported relevant agencies in taking robust action against those who commit sexual offences.ldquoWe have strengthened the criminal law on sexual offences, increased support to victims organisations and encouraged more victims to report their experiences.ldquoWhile the law in this area is kept under review, it is worth noting this is a similar test to other legal jurisdictions across the UK.ldquoAs the Cabinet Secretary said during a recent Parliamentary debate, the Scottish Government will raise the issue in future dialogue with the Scottish Law Commission.

title: plumbers-asked-to-pay-potentially-ruinous-pension-debts
story: The multi-employer Plumbing  Mechanical ServicesIndustry Pension Scheme is seeking to recover so-called Section  debts from a total of  employers, half of whom are based in Scotland and many of whom no longer employ any scheme members.:Scotlands big idea: what a merger of council pensions might meanThe money is being collected from the owners of businesses that have exited the scheme either because their firm has ceased trading or the staff they were contributing for have left their employment, with inidual sums expected to range from a few thousand to several million pounds.The schemersquos chief executive Kate Yates said the debts are due under legislation introduced in  that was designed to protect pensioners whose employer had gone bust. The debts have been repeatedly triggered in the plumbing scheme due to the high number of employers that have used it over the years.ldquoUnfortunately employer debt legislation is a case of well-intentioned legislation having unintended consequences because the sums of money employers are being asked to pay are quite large, she said.ldquoWe have a staggering amount of orphan liabilities, which relate to employers who are no longer contributing - about , employers in total have used the scheme.ldquoA debt is triggered when an employer winds up, goes insolvent or when their last employee leaves the scheme, but some that have triggered a debt may still be contributing to the scheme.ldquoA number of employers are very small and might only have one or two plumbers. They might have someone leave and then have a gap before someone  joins them - that gap would trigger a debt.Up until now the scheme has not collected any of these debts, with Ms Yates noting that its trustees, who had lobbied the Government for a change in the law, previously feltthe cost of doing so would be disproportionately high. They are looking to collect the debts now because the scheme, which has , members in Scotland and , in the rest of the UK, is expected to close to future accruals later this year.Fiona Hodgson, chief executive of the Scottish and Northern Ireland Plumbing Employersrsquo Federation , said the move has ldquonaturally raised serious concerns for our members.:Making a clear position on pensions.ldquoThe impact of Section  has the potential to be devastating for local businesses and the wider community, with the possibility of huge Section  debts looming over businesses who were simply trying to be good employers by providing a pension for their employees, she said.Affected businesses will start receiving demand letters between now and the end of June, although Ms Yates said that the scheme does not intend to collect every debt it issues a notice for. Where the sums are small, for example, it will be unlikely to seek payment.Meanwhile, the  firms that currently contribute to the pound billion scheme,  of which are based in Scotland, will have to find alternative pension arrangements for their employeesthe scheme closes to future accruals this summer as planned.Peter Mutch of law firm Aberdein Considine said that in addition to sourcing a defined contribution pension for their staff, employers will have to arrange benefits such as death in service cover that have until now been provided by the defined benefit scheme.Changes are being made to the pension because, while it has the funds to meet all its existing liabilities, contributions from non-retired members would have to rise signicantly in order for it to honour any further accruals.Trade union Unite is refusing to back the plan until it gets assurances about the level of contributions employers will pay into an alternative scheme.Its representative Bernard McAulay said: ldquoThis has been the jewel in the crown of pension schemes in the construction industry.ldquoOur members have contributed to it, they are very proud of it and itrsquos something they donrsquot want to lose.ldquoWersquore doing our best to make sure that what comes into being goes a long way to matching the industry standards.

title: mark-smith-first-brexit-then-scoxit-what-leaving-the-eu-can-teach-us-about-scottish-independence
story: The writer Will Self and the Tory MP Mark Francois were on BBC Politics Live to talk about the EU referendum but ended up trying to out-stare each other. Neither blinked and neither budged until, in the tradition of all pointless arguments between men, a woman intervened to break it up. Not only was it delightfully mad, it was a pretty good metaphor for the Brexit process: immovable, irrational, ridiculous, and a little bit childish. It was also a reminder that, on the endless, dficult subject of leaving the EU, we still havenrsquot found the man or woman we need to break up the fighting.:Paul Hutcheon: Brexit is a tragic plot line in a Tory soap operaIf there is any upside to be found in the whole thing , itrsquos this: the face-off between Leavers and Remainers could delay, and possibly frustrate, Brexit, although the longer-term consequences are still unclear. Over the weekend, we heard Nicola Sturgeon saythat the chaos of Brexit makes Scottish independence more likely. Her deputy Keith Brown also said the mess of Brexit might be the point at which momentum for independence becomes unstoppable. In other words, the SNP is hoping, still, that the Brexit chaos will drive voters into their arms.However, I wonderwe have really, properly looked for the clues in the chaos, the little signs to be found in the rubble, and asked what we can learn from them. The SNP keep arguing that the more people hate Brexit, the more they will love independence some unionists, on the other hand, argue Brexit is a clue to how hard negotiating Scottish independence will be. But letrsquos leave Mr Self and Mr Francois staring at each other for a minute shall we and take a look at the actual parallels between leaving the EU and leaving the UK. The picture is more mixed that you might think.Read more: Nicola Sturgeon signals Indyref push before For a start, the UK is not the same as the EU, although the dferences between them provide useful pointers. For instance ndash dficult as Brexit is ndash the fact that the UK is a sovereign state means it can leave the EU without having to make dficult decisions about what currency it uses for example it also doesnrsquot have to apply to join other international organisations or sort out its foreign or defence policies. All those questions have already been answered.Obviously, the same does not apply to Scotland ndash after voting for independence, it would be leaving a state rather than an organisation made up of states and would therefore have to make a lot of choices from scratch that the UK isnrsquot facing with Brexit. Scotland and rest of the UK also have shared assetsin a way that the UK and the EU donrsquot. All of this means, by definition, that Scotland leaving the UK would be more complicated than the UK leaving the EU, which, by extension, means the negotiations on independence could be even more hideous and confrontational than those on Brexit.Except in one happy respect: the dferences between the UK and the EU mean that there would, definitely, thankfully, be no equivalent to the backstop crisisScotland became independent because there isnrsquot a part of Scotland that would need to be treated dferently in the way Northern Ireland does. Scotland, geographically and politically, would be leaving the UK as a single whole country. Therefore, no Scottish backstop required, to the considerable relief of everyone.However, the absence of a backstop is not the same as an invisible border with England. Assuming Brexit goes ahead, the UK would be out of the single market and could restrict immigration from the EU. Equally, assuming Scotland joins the EU as an independent state, it would be following the four freedoms, including freedom of movement - therefore there would have to be checks at the Scottish border. Which leads to another of the lessons amid the chaos of Brexit: putting up barriers at borders is bad for the economy and the same would apply to Scotland.The other clues from the Brexit process are just as troubling, particularly on how the negotiations might go. Part of the problem for Theresa May has been that the EU is bigger and more powerful than the UK so the EU states have been able to dominate the negotiations and the same could apply to Scottish independence ndash the UK would be the bigger party and could end up imposing a deal thatrsquos bad for Scotland.Read more: Former Yes chief: Indyref coming down the trackAnd thatrsquos before we come to the political isions within Scotland itself. With Brexit, wersquove seen a minority government led by Mrs May thatrsquos paralysed by the split between hard and soft Brexiters and is reliant on a small party, the DUP, to get a deal through. But Nicola Sturgeon could find herself in a similar situation, except that the isions in her case would be between hard and soft nationalists arguing over how close to stay to the UK.Itrsquos also likely that, in trying to get any deal through Holyrood, the SNP would be reliant on a small party just as Mrs May is with the DUP, except that Mrs Sturgeon would be reliant on winning over hard nationalists in the Green party. The extreme Brexiters may have been the gremlins in the electrics of Brexit, but you can bet that,the SNP ever won a referendum on independence, there would be a similar type of hard Scottish nationalist pushing for an absolute form of separation. And the ldquoJacob Rees-Mogg in this situation, the ring-leader of the hard separatists, could be the leader of the Greens Patrick Harvie .All of these clues point to a dficult time after a vote for Scottish independence, quite apart from the fact that the dferences between the UK and the EU make another referendum dubious anyway ndash whatever Nicola Sturgeon and Keith Brown may have been hinting at over the weekend, the UK does not need permission to leave the EU, whereas Scotland has to get consent to leave the UK.Brexit has also taught us what happens when referendums are won by a slim margin. The argument goes on. Therersquos bitterness and chaos. The losers in the referendum keep pushing for another vote. The isions become deeper, and the wounds ooze more poison. This is precisely what has happened in the last two years over Brexit but take a close look at the chaos and you can see that itrsquos also what could happen to Scottish independence.

title: richard-leonard-targets-free-bus-travel-for-all-across-scotland
story: The Scottish Labour leader reiterated his partys pledge ahead of a debate on the issue in Holyrood this Wednesday.:Blow for Richard Leonard as leak reveals , Labour membership slump across ScotlandAnalysis of Transport Scotland statistics suggested % of people who have taken a bus journey in the day before being questioned were on an annual income of less than pound,.Only % earned more than pound,.Mr Leonard hailed the introduction of free bus travel for over s, however only % of the surveys respondents had a concessionary travel pass.Mr Leonard said: "Free bus travel for the over s, introduced by the last Labour government, has been one of the finest achievements of the Scottish Parliament."That is one reason why Labour wants to establish free bus travel for all, starting with extending the free bus pass to under s.:Why should travelling by bus be beneath those using Glasgow Airport "This move would overwhelmingly benefit the poorest in our society, and make a real dference to the economy."Every pound spent on concessionary bus travel generates almost pound in benefits to those bus users and to the wider economy."Thats why we are bringing a debate on our policy to the Scottish Parliament this week."

title: the-mystery-of-the-meteorite-that-struck-the-isle-of-lewis
story: Rugged, remote and largely uninhabited, apart from the hunting-shooting set who descend on the exclusive Morsgail Estate Lodge and a handful of other holiday homes, there is little to disrupt the Hebridean peace and quiet.But it is also the scene of perhaps one of the most bizarre puzzles that islanders ndash and many others far beyond the shores ndash haveencountered.After all, itrsquos not every day that the area is gripped by reports that a mystery object ndash thought to be a meteorite, and for a while simply branded as ldquoThe Thing from Space ndash had plunged to earth.:Scientist believes first meteorite to hit British Isles landed in ScotlandOr, for that matter, that an entire loch suddenly disappears. It was  years ago this November when locals had noted the abundance of shooting stars and the aurora danced almost every night. While the wind blew hard there were occasional days bathed in winter sunshine and near-cloudless skies.At Aird Uig, the RAF early warning radar station, senior aircraftman James Watt had just lit a cigarette. He was off duty and yanked open the window of his billet to clear the smoke just in time.ldquoIt was a very strange incident, he reflects. ldquoAs far as I was able to tell at the time, I was the only person that saw it from beginning to end. It was fascinating.The jury is still out ndash even after six decades ndash as to what exactly happened. Events of the next few minutes would perplex even the brightest expert minds, lure the most revered stargazer of his age, Sir Patrick Moore, on a bone-rattling journey from his home to the Western Isles, and spark a still inconclusive debate as to what on earth caused a massive crater and a whole loch to be drained of every ounce of water.Mr Watt, , originally from Dundee and now living in North Lincolnshire, is convinced of what he saw and heard. ldquoIt was a lovely sunny morning, he begins.ldquoFirst off, it was asit was a dot, or a full stop in the sky. ldquoI thought lsquowhat on earth is that rsquo As I kept looking at it, this lsquofull stoprsquo got larger and larger. It was a large sphere or a ball that was black or dark grey with a trail of smoke behind it.The object shot past the camp, roaring loudly as it went, he adds.ldquoIt was travelling at an angle of deg to deg and passed around  yards from my billet and no more than ft above my head, then carried on over the horizon. I noticed a number of sparks coming from it and there was a heck of a roar, like an express train.It was so loud, the camprsquos commanding officer stopped in mid-shave, towel wrapped around his neck, and came outside to see what had happened.Mr Watt later described what hersquod seen as a ldquoburning ball of hell,not a meteorite then some strange ball of gas, which screamed beyond the camp in the direction of two nearby lochans that were popular fishing spots for his RAF colleagues.A reconnaissance party was gathered ndash Mr Watt included ndash to head towards the two lochans where the mystery object was thought to have landed.What they found was not entirely what they expected. He said: ldquoThe north lochan was nearest to the camp, and below that was another small lochan. We walked through the peat bog to where the top lochan should have been, but all we saw was mud and a gorge in the land where it had been. The north lochan was completely drained of water.The two lochans ndash Loch nam Learga to the north and Loch Mor Sheacuteilabridh to the south ndash were around  yards apart, but the team that scoured the site found no meteorite fragments, no signs of scorching and, strangely for Mr Watt, no dead fish.:Evidence of biggest meteorite to hit Britain found in ScotlandldquoWe walked around this mud patch and couldnrsquot see a single dead fish, there was no smell either, he adds. It took several days for news of the incident to find its way  miles north to Stornoway after a chance remark by a local postman who came across the drained lochan, large swathes of churned up bogland, and, he claimed, a whf of burning.According to reports at the time, the higher lochan ndash  yards long and around  yards wide, around  yards uphill from its neighbour ndash appeared to have a hole torn in its south bank, while the water seemed to have drained with such force that the land around looked asit had been subjected to an earthquake, with channels ft deep carved into the peat.The curious incident sparked lively speculation. Some thought a meteorite, others a lightning strike, a few suggested it could be a Russian rocket targeting the radar camp, while others plumped for flood damaged lochan banks suddenly giving way. Some newspaper reports even hinted at space travellers.To help solve the mystery, an astrophysicist from the Royal Observatory of Edinburgh visited the site on the Uig moor, while newspapers chartered planes to fly overhead, snapping pictures to send around the world. But even the expert was unsure of what he was looking at.ldquoThe possibility that the island of Lewis was hit by the biggest meteorite to land in Britain in living memory grew slimmer after a visit to the site by an astrophysicist from the Royal observatory, reported The Herald of December , .ldquoThe scientist, Dr Hugh E Butler, thought heavy rain was the likely cause of the upheaval, it continued, before adding that even he wasnrsquot sure. ldquoDr Butler reached no firm conclusion.He said: lsquoSomething  may have triggered it off. A meteorite cannot be ruled out but unless any fragments are found I donrsquot think for that investigation is justied.rsquoThe area between Morsgail Lodge and the hamlet of Kinreasort five miles away, was under increasing media interest. Reports of the incident soon reached America and Africa, and the East Grinstead home of Sir Patrick Moore.After a day travelling north to Inverness, Sir Patrick caught a flight to Stornoway and then travelled by road to Morsgail Lodge and on to the site. Reports of meteorites were, he suggested, science fiction. Instead, Sir Patrick plumped for the missing loch as being a case of serious subsidence with the possibility of a methane explosion which may have thrown rocks high into the air.A bog burst ndash when peat becomes so saturated that a landslide occurs ndash seemed to many to be the logical answer.Mr Watt, however, is among those who remain convinced that there was something more to the odd events of late November .Did whatever it was simply sink deep into the peat, hidden from view  And why was there not a single dead fish to be seen ldquoYou donrsquot forget something like that, he says. ldquoIt was exciting, unusual. Irsquod never seen anything like it before and Irsquove not seen it since.

title: case-study-i-try-not-to-judge-people-harshly-i-was-like-that-once
story: It had been a surprise when her daughter, Abigail, now three, was born with the condition and she admits it was overwhelming at first."A lot of people first of all say sorry," said Mrs McCoy, who also has a six-year-old son and a daughter aged one. "I think people trying to be well-meaning, so I try not to judge people too harshly because a few years ago I didnt know any better myself."I had a mindset when Abigail was born of she wont achieve things, she might not live to be very old - now with experience, I realise thats not the case."Read more: Offensive terms like Mongol still widely used, warns Downs Syndrome charityMrs McCoy said her experience of health professionals had been mostly positive until she switched to a new GP after the family moved from Glasgow to Cambuslang."It was my first appointment and I was actually there to see about my little boy, not about Abigail," said Mrs McCoy, . "Wed just moved house and hed got a bit stressed out by the upheaval, so I went to talk to the GP about it."She was an older woman, late s, early s."She said to me something like I can see why youre neurotic having a daughter like her in your le, referring to Abigail, and suggested that thats why I was really there. I thought you dont really have the right to say that she makes my le dficult."Read: Parents reveal how having a daughter with Downs Syndrome has enriched their livesMrs McCoy, who coordinates sports development for schools, said she is sometimes frustrated when her mother-in-law refers to Abigail as a "Downs baby", and that one of the parents at Abigails nursery had made some "unhelpful comments".She said: "It was a mother who maybe wasnt that well-educated herself, and just assumed that Abigail wouldnt understand anything, that she was stupid, that there was no point in speaking to her directly."It was asshe wasnt a real person."I think we just need more awareness in general of what people with special needs can achieve. I think sometimes the focus is too much on what they cant do."A lot of people will say to me things like my goodness, your daughters beautul - I think that shocks them, that someone with special needs can look pretty."

title: scottish-labour-mp-criticised-for-calling-defections-a-necessary-cleansing
story: Paul Sweeney, the shadow Scotland Office minister, accused former colleagues Chris Leslie and Chuka Umunna ndash who left labour to join the new pro-EU grouping, whichalso includes ex-Tories ndash of being ldquoself-centred careerists.He also branded Mr Leslie ldquoaloof and arrogant, according to the Morning Star newspaper, adding: ldquoThe venom and the vitriol with which he addressed our front bench was a disgrace.Mr Sweeney, who represents Glasgow North East, reportedly made the comments at a meeting which took place on Friday night to mark the relaunch of the left-wing Tribune magazine.He said: ldquoTherersquos a necessary cleansing that has to happen in the margins.However, he expressed regret that Luciana Berger, the MP for Liverpoor Wavertree, had left the party amid accusations of bullying and bigotry centred around anti-Semitism.Mr Sweeney later said his phrasing had been a ldquoclumsy choice of words, adding: ldquoI meant no offence and apologise for any offence inadvertently caused on my part.Former Labour MP Ian Austin, who quit the party last month but did not join the new Independent Group, condemned the comments on Twitter.He wrote: ldquoA Labour MP says that people who have left Labour because of racism and extremism is a lsquonecessary cleansingrsquo.ldquoLetrsquos think about this: @pauljsweeney thinks the party is cleaner because people appalled about racism have left.One Labour MP told thePoliticsHome website: ldquoJeremy Corbyn has an opportunity here to show that he is serious about dealing with anti-Semitism and bullying in the Labour Party by sacking Sweeney from his shadow ministerial role and stripping him of the Labour whip."Anything less than that will be viewed as more preication on this issue.

title: former-international-boxer-launches-campaign-to-attract-more-men-into-nursing
story: Stevie Morrison, who hung up his gloves to become a nurse, is at the forefront of the MenRnurses drive launched this week.:NHS is at risk without more male nurses, says academicThe nursing profession has long sought to get rid of the tired stereotypes of nurses and the ldquocaring angels image in the belief that men should consider nursing, and that it is not just a career for women.There has been a small increase in male nursing applicants across Scotland, up from  last year to  this year according to the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service , but fewer than  per cent of nursing students are male ndash a figure that has hardly changed in the past decade.The social media campaign from Glasgow Caledonian University , where  per cent of the nursing teaching staff is male, is seeking to redress that balance and break down stereotypes in schools.Mr Morrison, a nursing lecturer at GCU who is also involved in the Men in Nursing universities research group reporting to the Scottish Government on how best to increase numbers, said: ldquoAs well as launching the @GCUMenRnurses social media campaign to raise awareness, we plan to take our message into schools.ldquoWersquoll be using male and female staff profiles to let the boys and young men see that nursing is an attractive career for them with a broad range of opportunities.ldquoResearch for the Men in Nursing study shows children as young as five have already formed ideas about gender roles and we think itrsquos important to get out there as early as possible, perhaps in nursery schools, to let them see men can be nurses too.ldquoIf you try to buy a nursersquos costume in a toy shop, itrsquos still usually a dress, with a picture of a girl model on the package ndash but nurses wear unisex scrubs these days. Meanwhile, a doctorrsquos costume will have a picture of a boy in a white coat with a stethoscope. Children are influenced by these stereotypes.:Gender bias against menMr Morrison, a former middleweight boxer who represented Scotland in boxing tournaments around the world, including the  Commonwealth Games, and who continues to work as a Boxing Scotland referee and judge, faced challenges when he was considering nursing as a career.ldquoI was helping to care for my gran, who had dementia, and after leaving school I worked in a hospital pharmacy, where I became interested in nursing. My supervisor encouraged me into the profession, but I never told any of my friends when I was applying for my diploma.ldquoMy best friend was also interested in a career in nursing and we used to talk about it in secret as there was such prejudice against men going into the profession.The father-of-four who has been in nursing for  years, added: ldquoNursing is a fantastic career with plenty of iety, flexibility and opportunities to progress ndash and Irsquod like more boys and men to know what a broad and deep profession it is. I believe nursing can become more attractive to men and that perceptions can change.ldquoWhen I was a child, you hardly saw any female police officers or firefighters. That has changed and both those professions are the better for being more erse ndash just as nursing will benefit from a workforce that better reflects our society.The social media campaign is backed by MSP John Mason, Vice Convener of the Economy, Energy and Fair Work Committee, who described the universityrsquos new drive as a ldquobrilliant idea. ldquoThe Scottish Parliament is very interested in the gender pay gap and how we can change the idea that men are going into one profession traditionally and women into another.Gordon Hill, a senior nursing lecturer at GCU, said: ldquoThe employment opportunities are there in nursing and there are also opportunities for career progression. Itrsquos a ied career that can see a nurse going from intensive care to research to community and clinical nursing."We have an ageing population and need more nurses and more of them should be men. Irsquod like to get rid of the use of lsquomale nursesrsquo. After all, you donrsquot talk about lsquofemale doctorsrsquo. A nurse is a nurse.

title: why-was-the-irish-flag-removed-from-dens-park-during-dundee-v-celtic
story: Video circulating around Twitter showedthe Irish flag being removed during Celtics - win over Dundee on Sunday.And the fan who had his flag removed said afterwards he was told to leave the ground after he went to retrieve it from stewards.While supporters groups voiced their disgust at the actions, Dundee said the reason was not sinister - stating simply that the flag breached rules as it was covering advertising.Fans Against Criminalisation, the group set up to move for the scrapping of the Offensive Behaviour at Football and Threatening Communications Scotland Act  criticised the overpolicing of Sundays match A FAC representative tweeted: "I am explicitly saying that it is entirely legitimate for someone who in any way, shape or form identies with Ireland to take such a flag to a Celtic game. This does not necessarily have a political connotation. But evenit did, that wouldnrsquot be an issue either."If a Rangers fan identities with the Union Jack then they have every right to wave one too. Wouldnrsquot take any issue with that either seeing as we live in an apparently free and democratic society."If members of Scotlandrsquos multi-generational Irish community, who make up much of the Celtic support, wish to celebrate the country of their ancestors why do you have a problem with that "The flag was being displayed in the away end during Sundays Scottish Premiership clash until it was take away. Footage shows a Celtic fan pursuing those who removed it and confronting them, before finally getting his flag back.And Joe ORourke of the Celtic Supporters Association who was concerned over what he perceived was a larger than normal police presence added: "There seemed to be a few incidents yesterday, one looked like a total farce when an Irish National Flag was pulled down by stewards who then ran away with it."There is absolutely nothing offensive about the National Flag of Ireland, so itrsquos hard to understand the actions of the steward. As far as I know, the owner got the flag back, so it begs the question, why take it in the first place He added in a blog post: "I have been following Celtic for over sixty years, Irsquom  years old and can walk down any street in Scotland without getting a second look from any copper, but once I put on my Celtic scarf and jacket I somehow become a threat to society."But John Nelms, managing director at Dundee, said: "The flag itself was taken down because it was covering up a board that was paid for by patrons that support the club."Thats the only reason it was taken down."They removed my flag but got it back##!!!!Unbowed and Unbroken #### #DUNCEL#StParticksDay pic AtChCmySome fans, however claimed that at least two banners were displayed covering advertising in the Dundee end, seemingly without being asked to remove them.

title: aberdeenshire council seeking government help over private water supplies
story: Aberdeenshire Council is to write to the Scottish Environment Minister to seek urgent help in getting more North-east homes with private water supplies connected to the mains network.Having helped some  homes which suffered serious water shortages last year, the local authority said it was mindful that  may not be a “one-off event”.Last year’s dry weather, reported officers, was “unprecedented” in terms of the extent of problems for private water supplies.The £, the council spent on providing intermediate bulk containers and bottled water for those in need, is currently being reclaimed from the Scottish Government.And latest surveys indicate that although no properties are currently being assisted by the council, water table levels remain at levels “much lower” than would be expected at this time of year.Members of the council’s Infrastructure Services Committee unanimously agreed that chair Peter Argyle write to Roseanna Cunningham seeking both the assistance of the Scottish Government and Scottish Water to mitigate against future shortages.They heard that Aberdeenshire has more than , properties – both domestic and non-domestic – which rely on private water supplies – the largest number of any local authority area in Scotland.While the upkeep of private water supplies is the responsibility of the property owner or landowner, supplies are vulnerable to fluctuations in quality and quantity, and are often not adequately maintained.In his letter to Ms Cunningham, Councillor Argyle states: “The public supply has many advantages over private water supplies and the overall aim should be to see as many properties as possible connected to the mains network.“The mains network should be extended to enable connections to be made, thereby reducing the number of properties on private supplies.“While it is recognised that it will not be possible to connect all properties to the public supply there are particular clusters of properties where it would be possible to do so.”The council also wants to see property owners being better educated in terms of water usage and a simplication of Scottish Water’s process forthose wishing to connect to the title: busy north east road to close for repairs
story: The A Ellon South Roundabout is set to benefit from #, worth of resurfacing improvements taking place next week.The resurfacing improvements will address defects in the road surface of the roundabout as well as a section of the A just over m long to the north of the roundabout, creating a smoother and safer journey for motorists.The overnight surfacing works are scheduled to start Monday  March and will take seven nights to complete. The project will take place between .pm and .am each night with improvements expected to be completed by .am on Wednesday  March. No works are programmed for Saturday or Sunday nights.To ensure the safety of road workers as well as motorists, an overnight road closure will be in place on the A each night. For traffic travelling north, a ersion route will be in place via the old Athrough Foveran, onto the B, along the B and onto the A through Ellon where motorists will then re-join the A. All motorists travelling southbound will be erted via the A, B, B and along the old Athrough Foveran, where they will re-join the A. The ersion in place overnight will add around  miles or  minutes onto road user’s journeys.All traffic management will be removed from the carriageway during the daytime.Consultation has taken place with local residents and the local authority in advance of the resurfacing to make them aware of the traffic management arrangements and to minimise any inconvenience.Commenting on the improvements, Andy Thompson, BEAR Scotland’s North East Representative, said: “This £, project has been designed to improve the general condition and safety of the Ellon South Roundabout for motorists.“The traffic management is essential to ensure the safety of road workers and motorists during the project. We’ve taken steps to minimise disruption for road users as much as possible during the improvements, including carrying out the works overnight and avoiding working Saturday and Sunday nights.“We thank motorists for their patience in advance while our teams carry out these works on the A. We encourage road users to plan their journeys in advance by checking the Traffic Scotland website for up to date traffic information and allow some extra time to reach their destination.”Real-time journey planning information can be obtained by visiting www.trafficscotland.org or twitter @ trafficscotland.Materials removed from the existing carriageway will be recycled using SEPA approved methods.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.fraserburghherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Brew Toon is one of six local businesses to be shorlisted." title: amazing book of finds on the site of the awpr
story: A new book highlighting the artefacts and structures found during archaeological excavations on the AWPR project is now available.The book, a summary of the discoveries called Highway Through History, provides information on land use and settlement in the north east over the past , years, including Roman bread ovens, prehistoric roundhouses and a cremation complex.Michael Matheson, Cabinet Secretary for Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity, said: “The sites identied along the route are truly remarkable but would have remained undiscovered had the new bypass not been built. This underlines the importance of the value we place on meeting our environmental obligations as we plan and construct new infrastructure. This book, which provides valuable details on the archaeological finds, will be essential reading for everyone who has an interest in the North-East’s history.”Bruce Mann, Archaeologist for the council, explained: “This book provides more details on our fascinating discoveries from the archaeological works carried out on the AWPR site. For instance, a very unexpected discovery was the presence of Roman activity at Milltimber, likely dating from around   AD. Ninety bread ovens were uncovered, which were probably constructed by the Roman army at a time of invasion led by the Roman General Agricola. However, no evidence of an associated camp was found, which is unusual for these types of features. We can only speculate as to why the ovens were in this location.“Going back to the very earliest finds, there was also evidence of stone tool production dating between about , and , BC at Milltimber, a near unprecedented body of evidence which pushes back our understanding of human activity in north east Scotland by several thousand years.”Bruce continued:“Bronze Age activity was identied from Nether Beanshill in the form of a roundhouse and contemporary cremation complex dating from around , to , BC. The burial comprised of an urn in which the cremated remains of an inidual in their s had been placed. This urn was placed in a pit which was then marked by a horseshoe-shaped arrangement of timber posts. Two other similar burials were also uncovered.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Gillian Martinwith Emma Harper, who launched the public consultation exercise."   with Emma Harper, who launched the public consultation exercise." title: flexi schooling to be investigated by aberdeenshire council
story: The potential introduction of flexi-schooling in Aberdeenshire is to be debated by councillors this week.North Kincardine councillor Alison Evison formally sought a detailed analysis of flexi-schooling through the Member Promoted Issueprocess.The Scottish Labour councillor said that some parents had asked for the initiative to become an option in Aberdeenshire.The authority’s Education and Children’s Service Committee will discuss a report from officers on Thursday next week.In her MPI Councillor Evison states: “This would allow themto develop an inidualised programme of education for their child in consultation with their local primary school and in the best interests of their child.”She says that within the principles of GIRFEC – Getting It Right For Every Child – flexi-schooling would enable parents to opt for a “combination of provision”, which could involve a number of days each week in school and a day or two in alternative provision such as outdoorlearning or in home schooling.She says: “This option would be a radical departure from current practice, but it is one which merits proper analysis and reasoned consideration of both the potential benefits and disadvantages.”Councillors will be told by officers that there is “limited evidence” of a clear and definitive definition of what is understood by flexi-schooling.Perceived advantages include the freedom of parents to spend more time with their children and providing children with an the opportunity to learn more in-depth than they might at school, with more out-of-school trips and inidual adult attention.However, among the disadvantages would be that some children who attend school on a full-time might “resent” the fact that their peers do not have to attend five days a week, and get to participate in other activities such as museum and zoo outings while they are in the classroom.Officers say it may also become harder for flexi-schooled children to re-adjust to school and it could have an affect on the child’s attainment especiallythey are not taught in the same way that the school teaches in preparation for assessments exams.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch story: Scottish Sea Farms is preparing to open its new salmon farm off Lober Rock in Scapa Flow.The new farm will go live in autumn with the company announcing a total infrastructure investment of £. million — of which  per cent will be spent with Scottish businesses.Contracts for works have been awarded to ious companies throughout the country, with local company Marine Leask securing moorings, a barge and pens, while on Sanday, Gael Force Fusion will construct the salmon pens — work which is expected to take at least three months.The new farm will create six new full-time roles and lead to further job creation across the supply chain.Scottish Sea Farms’ managing director Jim Gallagher said: “These orders will equip our new farm with the latest technologies, ensuring we’re Scottish Technical Standard  compliant and giving our salmon the very best environment in which to grow.#We’ve worked with several of these suppliers for many years now as part of our long-standing policy of buying Scottish wherever possible and know their products to be tried and tested with regards to withstanding Orkney marine conditions.”Managing director of Leask Marine, Douglas Leask added: “This latest expansion is great news, both for Scottish Sea Farms and locally. title: campaign offers advice for dog owners around livestock
story: Dog owners across Scotland are being encouraged to take extra care around livestock when enjoying the great outdoors this spring.Scottish Natural Heritageis running a national radio and digital campaign, based on advice from the National Access Forum, to help dog owners to explore their local natural areas without disturbing vulnerable young animals during the lambing season.The key message of the campaign — which has been developed alongside Police Scotland, NFU Scotland, Scottish Land and Estates and The Kennel Club — is to keep dogs out of fields with young farm animals and on a short lead or close at heel when livestock are around. If cattle react aggressively, release your dog and take the shortest, safest route out of the field.The Scottish Outdoor Access Code website provides more information, including online video tutorials covering everything from teaching a dog to be relaxed around livestock through to dog walker etiquette and legal responsibilities.Dog behaviourist and trainer Natalie Light said: “These videos are packed full of great tips that will give dog owners the information and skills to have fun and safe walks in Scotland’s outdoors as well as understand their rights and responsibilities under the Scottish Outdoor Access Code.“I hope they encourage everyone to get involved and have the confidence to enjoy getting out and about with their pets this spring.”Farmers and other land managers are also encouraged to support responsible access with dogs by following the guidance in the Scottish Outdoor Access Code, for example by avoiding putting sheep close to lambing in fields with well-used routes, or indicating reasonable alternatives. If necessary, local access officers can also provide advice.More information is available on the Scottish Outdoor Access Code website.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: farmers urged to get their single application form handed in
story: newsFarmers urged to get their Single Application Form handed inMarch ,  at : am vw, px"  With the Single Application Formwindow having opened today, the farmers union in Scotland, NFU Scotland, is encouraging crofters and farmers to prioritise filling out their forms online before the May  deadline.A combination of Brexit uncertainty, spring work, lambing and calving means that many farmers and crofters will have many other things occupying their minds at this busy time of year. At this busy time of year, the union is urging applicants to start filling out their SAF and is reminding them that, as things stand, it#s business as usual for all CAP schemes.The union has also said the online application process has seen signicant improvements in recent years and the clear majority of applications are now made online. By submitting your application online, the system will flag any errors before submitting your application.Paper forms will not be automatically posted out and must instead be requested from Local Area Offices. Iniduals can also go to their Local Area Office where staff will be on hand to assist those completing their form online.NFU Scotland president Andrew McCornick said: “Brexit chaos and confusion are dominating the headlines and generating uncertainty. The crucial thing for all farmers and crofters to bear in mind is that, as things stand, it is business as usual for all CAP schemes and that includes completing this year’s SAF.“The SAF window, which will run from  March to  May, will be punctured by Brexit headlines but we don’t want anyone to inadvertently be distracted from this important process. SAF forms are the most important forms that Scottish farmers fill out every year and I would encourage all members to begin working on their forms as soon as possible to ensure they meet the  May deadline.“For the second year, paper forms will not be automatically sent out by post, with the Scottish Government continuing to encourage claimants to complete their SAF online. Whether you are happy to switch to online or are sticking to paper, the important thing is to take plenty of time and not leave it to the last-minute. Remember, it is the most important day’s work in any farmer’s year.”• Online applications can be submitted via the Scottish Government#s rural payments and services website, at www.ruralpayments.org.A paper copy of the Single Application Form can be picked up at the Scottish Government#s office, in the Government Buildings, on Junction Road, Kirkwall. Paper forms can be handed there, or sent to: Scottish Government, Agriculture and Rural Economy, Government Buildings, Tankerness Lane, Kirkwall, KW AQ.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
